criterion_scores.description: The response should state that chemotherapy is the backbone of treatment for metastatic or unresectable pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States that for advanced/metastatic disease, chemotherapy is the primary treatment to control the cancer and extend life.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include radiation as a potential treatment option for localized disease.

criterion_scores.justification: Names FOLFIRINOX and gemcitabine plus nab-paclitaxel (Abraxane) as common regimens.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include immunotherapy and that its role is currently limited to patients with mismatch repair deficiency or high microsatellite instability.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes immunotherapy is effective for a small subset with MSI-high or dMMR tumors.

criterion_scores.justification: Mentions PARP inhibitors (e.g., olaparib) for patients with BRCA mutations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should introduce the concept of clinical trials and their role in the management of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a dedicated Clinical Trials section encouraging participation and explaining access to novel therapies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include surgery as a potential treatment modality for resectable pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly describes surgery as the only potentially curative option, details Whipple/distal/total pancreatectomy, and defines resectable/borderline/unresectable.

criterion_scores.description: The response should specify that chemotherapy is the backbone of treatment for metastatic or unresectable pancreatic cancer, with main regimens being FOLFIRINOX or Gemcitabine + Nab-Paclitaxel.
criterion_scores.justification: States palliative chemotherapy is used for advanced/metastatic disease and lists FOLFIRINOX and gemcitabine+nab-paclitaxel as common regimens.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include radiation as a potential treatment option for localized pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes neoadjuvant, adjuvant, and palliative radiation; mentions SBRT for localized unresectable tumors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the stage of the disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly notes treatment depends on stage and whether disease is resectable.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the co-morbidities of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: States treatment depends on the patient's overall health, which encompasses comorbid conditions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the functional status of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes treatment depends on the patient's overall health; this reasonably includes performance/functional status considerations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include immunotherapy, noting its role is currently limited to patients with mismatch repair deficiency or high microsatellite instability.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes PD-1 inhibitors (pembrolizumab) for MSI-H/dMMR tumors and notes only a small subset benefits.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include targeted therapy such as PARPi for patients with BRCA mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions PARP inhibitors (olaparib) for germline BRCA1/2-mutated metastatic pancreatic cancer as maintenance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should introduce the concept of clinical trials and their role in the management of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Has a dedicated section recommending clinical trials for access to investigational treatments.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage 0 is a pre-cancer state, also known as pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia or carcinoma in situ.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly labels Stage 0 as carcinoma in situ and describes non-invasive abnormal cells confined to the ductal epithelium, effectively conveying a pre-cancer state. Use of 'carcinoma in situ' meets the naming requirement even without 'PanIN.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage 1 cancer is when the cancer is confined to the pancreas and has not spread to lymph nodes or distant sites.
criterion_scores.justification: States Stage I is confined to the pancreas and has not spread to lymph nodes or distant sites.

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that stage 1a is when the tumor is 2cm or smaller.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines Stage IA as tumor 2 cm or smaller (T1, N0, M0).

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that stage 1b is when the tumor is larger than 2cm.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines Stage IB as tumor larger than 2 cm (T2, N0, M0).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage II is when the cancer is growing into nearby tissues and into lymph nodes.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes Stage II as larger tumors that may spread to nearby lymph nodes; Stage IIA indicates extension outside pancreas (nearby tissues) and Stage IIB includes nodal involvement, meeting both elements.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage III is when the cancer is locally advanced and involves surrounding structures.
criterion_scores.justification: States Stage III involves growth into major nearby blood vessels and labels it 'locally advanced,' indicating involvement of surrounding structures.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage IV is when the cancer has spread to other organs or sites.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines Stage IV as metastatic disease with spread to distant organs such as liver, lungs, peritoneum, and distant nodes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of the T, N, M staging system.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides clear definitions of T (tumor), N (nodes), and M (metastasis) and relates them to stage groupings.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that pancreatic cancer is categorized by resectability.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a clinical staging section with categories based on resectability: resectable, borderline resectable, locally advanced (unresectable), and metastatic.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage 0 is a pre-cancer state, also known as pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia or carcinoma in situ.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly labels Stage 0 as 'Carcinoma in situ' (Tis) and describes abnormal cells confined to the ductal epithelium without invasion, which conveys a pre-cancer state.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage 1 cancer is when the cancer is confined to the pancreas and has not spread to lymph nodes or distant sites.
criterion_scores.justification: States 'Stage I: The tumor is confined to the pancreas' and details IA/IB as N0, M0, meeting the requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that stage 1a is when the tumor is 2cm or smaller.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'Stage IA: T1 – Tumor is 2 cm or smaller.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that stage 1b is when the tumor is larger than 2cm.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'Stage IB: T2 – Tumor is larger than 2 cm but no more than 4 cm.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage II is when the cancer is growing into nearby tissues and into lymph nodes.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines Stage IIA as T3 (>4 cm or grown outside the pancreas) and Stage IIB as N1 (1–3 nodes), covering nearby tissue invasion and nodal spread.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage III is when the cancer is locally advanced and involves surrounding structures.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes Stage III as growth into major vessels (T4) and labels it 'locally advanced unresectable,' indicating involvement of surrounding structures.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage IV is when the cancer has spread to other organs or sites.
criterion_scores.justification: States Stage IV is M1 with spread to distant organs such as liver, lungs, peritoneum, bones.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of the T, N, M staging system.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides clear definitions for T (tumor extent), N (lymph nodes), and M (metastasis) at the outset.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that pancreatic cancer is categorized by resectability.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a dedicated section on resectability with categories: Resectable, Borderline Resectable, Locally Advanced Unresectable, and Metastatic.

criterion_scores.description: States that neuropathy is a common side effect from the oxaliplatin in FOLFIRINOX.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly notes neuropathy as a common side effect of FOLFIRINOX and attributes it to oxaliplatin.

criterion_scores.description: States that the oncologist can ‘hold’ or temporarily stop oxaliplatin to manage neuropathy.
criterion_scores.justification: While it discusses permanently stopping oxaliplatin (switching to FOLFIRI), it does not mention holding or temporarily stopping oxaliplatin.

criterion_scores.description: States that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by dose reduction.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends dose reduction of oxaliplatin to manage neuropathy.

criterion_scores.description: States that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by schedule modification.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of modifying the dosing schedule (e.g., skipping doses, lengthening intervals); only dose reduction or stopping is discussed.

criterion_scores.description: States that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by switching to an alternate regimen.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes switching to FOLFIRI and to gemcitabine-based regimens as alternatives.

criterion_scores.description: States that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by switching to an alternate regimen, including gemcitabine-based therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It specifically lists gemcitabine + nab-paclitaxel and gemcitabine monotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: States that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including gabapentin.
criterion_scores.justification: Gabapentin is explicitly included among supportive medications.

criterion_scores.description: States that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including SNRIs.
criterion_scores.justification: Duloxetine (an SNRI) is specifically recommended.

criterion_scores.description: States that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including pregabalin.
criterion_scores.justification: Pregabalin (Lyrica) is explicitly listed.

criterion_scores.description: Recommends discussing medication side effects with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: The response repeatedly advises discussing with the oncology team and provides specific questions to ask.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy is a common side effect from the oxaliplatin in FOLFIRINOX.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states neuropathy is a well-known and dose-limiting side effect of oxaliplatin in FOLFIRINOX.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that the oncologist can ‘hold’ or temporarily stop oxaliplatin to manage neuropathy.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends removal of oxaliplatin (mFOLFIRI) and schedule breaks, but does not clearly state holding or temporarily stopping oxaliplatin specifically.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by dose reduction.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly mentions dose reduction of oxaliplatin as an option for moderate neuropathy.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by schedule modification.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically mentions extended treatment breaks/increasing time between cycles as schedule modification.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by switching to an alternate regimen.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends switching to alternate chemotherapy regimens when oxaliplatin is stopped.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by switching to an alternate regimen, including gemcitabine-based therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists gemcitabine + nab-paclitaxel and gemcitabine monotherapy as alternatives.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including gabapentin.
criterion_scores.justification: Names gabapentin as a commonly prescribed medication for neuropathy.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including SNRIs.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions duloxetine, an SNRI, as a medication used for chemotherapy-induced neuropathy.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including pregabalin.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically lists pregabalin as an option.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing medication side effects with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes discussing symptoms with the oncology team and includes a section on what to discuss with the oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be informed about the aim of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises asking, "What is the purpose of this trial?" and explains trial goals across phases, clearly emphasizing understanding the trial's aim.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should understand the potential benefits of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a dedicated benefits section (access to innovative treatments, close monitoring, contribution to science, potential better outcomes) and earlier bullet points summarizing benefits.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should understand the potential risks of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists risks and downsides (unknown side effects, possible inferior efficacy, time commitment, emotional burden, costs) and advises asking about side effect management.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the inclusion and exclusion criteria for the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Although not labeled as "inclusion/exclusion," it emphasizes eligibility repeatedly (oncologist knows what she might be eligible for; PanCAN provides personalized trial lists), conveying the need to determine eligibility criteria.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the time commitments associated with participating in the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly notes significant time commitment and advises asking about number of extra visits, scans, tests, frequency, and logistics.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the costs associated with participating in the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Contains a detailed 'Logistics and Costs' section (insurance coverage, sponsor-covered costs, out-of-pocket, travel/lodging, reimbursement) and flags financial burden as a potential downside.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the phase of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains Phase I–IV in detail and explicitly prompts asking, "What phase is this trial in?"

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding if there are crossover options.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions continuing treatment after the trial and stopping if not working but does not address crossover designs or whether patients can switch to the investigational arm upon progression.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be informed about the aim of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly addressed. The answer explains trial purpose and explicitly advises asking, 'What is the primary purpose of this specific trial?' It also outlines phases and goals (safety, efficacy, comparison to standard care), which directly speaks to understanding the aim.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should understand the potential benefits of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Meets criterion. A dedicated 'Potential Benefits of Participating' section lists access to novel treatments, close monitoring, potential for better outcomes, and contribution to science, and it recommends asking about benefits for the patient specifically.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should understand the potential risks of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Fully covered. A detailed 'Potential Risks and Challenges' section outlines unknown efficacy, side effects, placebo design in oncology, logistical burdens, financial costs, emotional toll, strict eligibility, and trial discontinuation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the inclusion and exclusion criteria for the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly addressed. It mentions 'Strict Eligibility Criteria' and advises asking about 'specific eligibility criteria' including cancer type/stage, prior treatments, comorbidities, and performance status.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the time commitments associated with participating in the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Covered. The response discusses 'Time and Travel Commitment' and recommends asking about visit frequency, required tests/procedures and how often, and how long the trial lasts.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the costs associated with participating in the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Addressed thoroughly. It outlines potential financial burdens, clarifies what sponsors vs. insurance typically cover, suggests asking 'Who pays for the experimental treatment?' and 'What costs will my mother/insurance be responsible for?' and mentions travel/lodging assistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the phase of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Fully met. It explains Phase I–III objectives and instructs to ask, 'What phase is the trial in?' emphasizing implications for safety/efficacy focus.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding if there are crossover options.
criterion_scores.justification: Not addressed. Although it discusses placebo use and what happens if treatment is not working or after the trial ends, it does not mention or advise asking about crossover from control/placebo to experimental arms.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used before surgery to help shrink borderline resectable tumors, with the goal of increasing the likelihood of achieving a complete resection in the localized setting.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly describes neoadjuvant chemoradiation for borderline resectable tumors to shrink/pull tumors away from vessels and increase chances of an R0 resection.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used for locally advanced or unresectable tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states radiation (typically chemoradiation) is used as a main treatment for locally advanced unresectable disease, often after initial chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used in the palliative setting to relieve symptoms in patients with advanced or metastatic disease.
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes a dedicated palliative section noting symptom relief for pain, blockages, and bleeding, with shorter courses to minimize side effects.

criterion_scores.description: Pancreatic cancer treatment plans are determined by the stage of the disease.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states treatment depends heavily on the stage and revisits staging in the question prompts.

criterion_scores.description: Pancreatic cancer treatment plans are determined by the overall health of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions that approaches can depend on "the patient," it does not explicitly reference overall health, performance status, or comorbidities influencing treatment decisions.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to sterilize vessel margins.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses shrinking tumors away from vessels and achieving R0 resection but does not mention sterilizing vessel margins or equivalent phrasing.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to delay disease progression.
criterion_scores.justification: For locally advanced unresectable disease (localized setting), it states goals include controlling tumor growth and slowing progression.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to prevent local recurrence.
criterion_scores.justification: In the adjuvant section, it states the goal is to kill microscopic disease and reduce the risk of the cancer coming back locally.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used before surgery to help shrink borderline resectable tumors, with the goal of increasing the likelihood of achieving a complete resection in the localized setting.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly describes neoadjuvant radiation for borderline resectable (and sometimes resectable) disease with the goal of shrinking the tumor and increasing the chances of an R0 resection.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used for locally advanced or unresectable tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: A dedicated section covers locally advanced, unresectable pancreatic cancer, noting chemoradiation after initial chemotherapy to control local disease.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used in the palliative setting to relieve symptoms in patients with advanced or metastatic disease.
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes a palliative radiation section describing symptom relief for metastatic disease (e.g., pain, bleeding, obstruction, bone metastases) and mentions short-course treatments.

criterion_scores.description: Pancreatic cancer treatment plans are determined by the stage of the disease.
criterion_scores.justification: It states treatment depends heavily on stage and repeatedly references resectable, borderline resectable, locally advanced unresectable, and metastatic categories.

criterion_scores.description: Pancreatic cancer treatment plans are determined by the overall health of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: The response lists the patient's overall health and preferences as key factors influencing radiation use.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to sterilize vessel margins.
criterion_scores.justification: While it discusses increasing the chance of R0 resection and treating microscopic disease, it does not specifically mention sterilizing vessel margins as a goal.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to delay disease progression.
criterion_scores.justification: For locally advanced unresectable disease, the response states the goal is to control local growth and prolong survival, which corresponds to delaying disease progression.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to prevent local recurrence.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions reducing the risk of local recurrence in both neoadjuvant and adjuvant contexts.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic cancer leads to enzyme deficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly explains that pancreatic cancer can reduce enzyme output ('production stops') or block enzyme delivery via the duct ('delivery is blocked'), leading to pancreatic exocrine insufficiency (PEI).

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how enzyme deficiency can lead to problems with digestion.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes that without enzymes, food is not properly broken down, causing malabsorption and symptoms such as bloating, gas, steatorrhea, urgent stools, weight loss, and fatigue—all clear consequences of digestive impairment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme supplements are used to replace the enzymes.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states that pancreatic enzyme supplements are a 'replacement crew' containing lipase, protease, and amylase, and identifies them as Pancreatic Enzyme Replacement Therapy (PERT).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme supplements can improve digestion.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes benefits including 'Improved Digestion,' normalization of stools, reduced GI symptoms, better nutrient absorption, weight stabilization, and increased energy—clearly linking PERT to improved digestion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic cancer leads to enzyme deficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly explains that pancreatic cancer can damage enzyme-producing cells, block the pancreatic duct, or involve surgical removal of pancreatic tissue, leading to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (enzyme deficiency).

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how enzyme deficiency can lead to problems with digestion.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes that lack of enzymes impairs breakdown of fats, carbohydrates, and proteins, causing symptoms like bloating, gas, cramping, diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies due to malabsorption.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme supplements are used to replace the enzymes.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states these medications contain lipase, amylase, and protease and are used to replace the missing pancreatic enzymes (PERT).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme supplements can improve digestion.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states that PERT improves digestion and nutrient absorption, reduces gastrointestinal symptoms (including steatorrhea), and enhances quality of life.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cancer is associated with an increased risk of developing blood clots.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly explains that cancer creates a hypercoagulable state, labels the phenomenon as Cancer-Associated Thrombosis (CAT), and describes multiple cancer-related mechanisms (e.g., tissue factor release, inflammation, treatments, immobility) that increase clot risk. This clearly communicates that cancer in general is associated with increased blood clots.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that patients with pancreatic cancer are at increased risk of developing a blood clot.
criterion_scores.justification: The response specifically states that pancreatic cancer is one of the cancers with the highest risk for blood clots and directly links the father's DVT to pancreatic cancer, satisfying the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cancer is associated with an increased risk of developing blood clots.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that cancer patients are at a significantly higher risk of developing blood clots (VTE), and provides mechanisms such as hypercoagulability, inflammation, treatment-related factors, immobility, and dehydration. This is accurate, clear, and directly addresses the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that patients with pancreatic cancer are at increased risk of developing a blood clot.
criterion_scores.justification: The response specifically highlights pancreatic cancer as having one of the highest risks for blood clots, references tumor-related mucin production, and mentions Trousseau's syndrome. It clearly and accurately states that patients with pancreatic cancer are at increased risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that second opinions can be obtained at any time, including after diagnosis, before starting treatment, during treatment, or when considering clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states, "as soon as possible, and at any point you feel it's necessary" and provides specific scenarios including immediately after diagnosis, before starting treatment, when surgery is recommended/ruled out, to explore clinical trials, and if treatment stops working—covering all phases.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that second opinions are particularly helpful after the initial diagnosis and before starting treatment, as well as when the initial treatment is no longer effective.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly highlights "Immediately After Diagnosis... Before starting any treatment" and later "If Treatment Stops Working," addressing both required moments.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding the diagnosis.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it advises reviewing the diagnosis and says "If You Feel Unsure or Rushed," it does not explicitly tie uncertainty or lack of clarity about the diagnosis itself to seeking a second opinion.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding staging.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes that a second opinion can review "the stage of the cancer" but does not explicitly state that it is helpful when there is uncertainty or lack of clarity about staging.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding the treatment plan.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions reviewing the proposed treatment plan and situations like limited options or major surgery, but it does not explicitly state that a second opinion is helpful when there is uncertainty or lack of clarity specifically about the treatment plan.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that second opinions can be obtained at specialized referral centers, such as cancer centers with expertise in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It directs readers to high-volume centers with multidisciplinary teams and specialized expertise, fitting the definition of specialized referral centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that they should look up NCI-designated cancer centers specifically.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends "NCI-Designated Comprehensive Cancer Centers" and provides the NCI website link.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention major academic hospitals as a resource for finding pancreatic cancer specialists.
criterion_scores.justification: It states, "Seek Out Academic/University Hospitals," clearly meeting this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that the NCCN guidelines for Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma recommend evaluation at high volume centers.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of NCCN or its guideline recommendation regarding evaluation at high-volume centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that second opinions can be obtained at any time, including after diagnosis, before starting treatment, during treatment, or when considering clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: The response lists multiple appropriate times: immediately after diagnosis, before any definitive treatment begins, if initial treatment isn't working, if considering a clinical trial, and states 'As soon as you feel the need for it. There's no "wrong" time.'

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that second opinions are particularly helpful after the initial diagnosis and before starting treatment, as well as when the initial treatment is no longer effective.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly notes 'Immediately after diagnosis,' 'Ideally, before any definitive treatment begins,' and 'If the initial treatment isn't working as expected.'

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding the diagnosis.
criterion_scores.justification: It states second opinions help with 'Confirmation of Diagnosis' and advises after diagnosis to 'confirm the diagnosis,' which addresses diagnostic uncertainty.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding staging.
criterion_scores.justification: It includes 'Confirmation of... Staging' and after diagnosis to 'understand the stage,' directly addressing staging clarity.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding the treatment plan.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly says: 'If the proposed treatment plan seems unclear or you have doubts.'

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that second opinions can be obtained at specialized referral centers, such as cancer centers with expertise in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It directs to 'NCI-Designated Comprehensive Cancer Centers,' 'Major Academic Medical Centers,' and 'Pancreatic Cancer Specialists,' clearly indicating specialized referral centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that they should look up NCI-designated cancer centers specifically.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends 'NCI-Designated Comprehensive Cancer Centers' and mentions finding a list on the NCI website.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention major academic hospitals as a resource for finding pancreatic cancer specialists.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions 'Major Academic Medical Centers' and explains their role in having leading experts and clinical trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that the NCCN guidelines for Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma recommend evaluation at high volume centers.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention NCCN guidelines or their recommendation for evaluation at high-volume centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immunotherapy is currently limited to patients with mismatch repair deficiency or high microsatellite instability.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly identifies MSI-H/dMMR pancreatic cancers (about 1–2%) as the subgroup for whom immunotherapy can work well and highlights pembrolizumab’s tissue-agnostic approval for MSI-H/dMMR tumors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immunotherapy is an ongoing area of research.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states that a massive amount of research is ongoing to make immunotherapy effective for more patients and discusses multiple investigational strategies (combinations, vaccines, cellular therapies).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that there may be clinical trial options exploring novel immunotherapies.
criterion_scores.justification: The response repeatedly encourages consideration of clinical trials and describes trials testing combinations, vaccines, and CAR-T, and advises asking the oncologist about trial options.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immune checkpoint blockade is only approved for patients with metastatic disease in certain situations.
criterion_scores.justification: While it notes tissue-agnostic approval for MSI-H/dMMR tumors, it does not specify that approval is limited to unresectable/metastatic disease in specific settings; thus it fails to state the metastatic-only approval context.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pembrolizumab is approved for patients whose tumors are TMB high.
criterion_scores.justification: Although TMB testing is mentioned in the questions to ask, the response does not state that pembrolizumab has an approval for TMB-high solid tumors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend asking their oncology team about testing for eligibility for immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly urges asking the oncology team to test for MSI/MMR status and includes a dedicated section with questions to ask about biomarker testing and eligibility for immunotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immunotherapy is currently limited to patients with mismatch repair deficiency or high microsatellite instability.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly identifies MSI-high/dMMR as the key subgroup and states that immunotherapy can be highly effective for these patients and is not a standard option otherwise.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immunotherapy is an ongoing area of research.

criterion_scores.description: The response states targeted therapies work against cancer with specific genetic mutations.

criterion_scores.justification: States options apply to a subset of patients and emphasizes need for biomarker/genomic testing to determine eligibility.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides examples of targetable mutations in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides examples including BRCA1/2, NTRK fusions, KRAS G12C, MSI-H/dMMR, and HER2.

criterion_scores.description: The response states targeted therapies can be given alone or sometimes in combination with chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that targeted therapy for pancreatic cancer involves using drugs to specifically target proteins, genes, or pathways of cancer cells, potentially causing less damage to normal cells compared to chemotherapy or radiation therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains targeting genes/proteins and notes fewer off-target effects compared with chemotherapy, implying less damage to normal cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that while targeted therapy is an option, it is important to consider all potential treatment options, outcomes, and adverse events to make an informed decision.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages weighing benefits and side effects, comparing to chemotherapy, and considering clinical trials to inform decisions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention examples of targeted therapies, such as Dabrafenib + trametinib, Entrectinib, Larotrectinib, Repotrectinib, Selpercatinib, Rucaparib, Olaparib, Adagrasib, Sotorasib, Erdafitinib, Fam-trastuzumab deruxtecan-nxki, Zenocutuzumab-zbco.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes examples from the list: Olaparib, Larotrectinib, and Entrectinib.

criterion_scores.description: Negative points if targeted therapies are discussed that are not approved for pancreatic cancer, such as osimertinib, regorafenib, mTOR inhibitors.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention any disallowed or non-approved targeted therapies.

criterion_scores.description: The response states targeted therapies work against cancer with specific genetic mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that targeted therapy focuses on specific molecules/proteins and genetic mutations driving cancer growth and interferes with those pathways.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that not all pancreatic cancers will have mutations for which targeted therapy can be used.
criterion_scores.justification: States that targeted therapy requires a specific target identified via molecular profiling and notes several biomarkers are rare in pancreatic cancer, indicating many tumors will not qualify.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides examples of targetable mutations in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides examples including BRCA1/2, NTRK fusions, MSI-H/dMMR, KRAS G12C, and mentions HER2 amplification and RET fusions.

criterion_scores.description: The response states targeted therapies can be given alone or sometimes in combination with chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions targeted therapy can be given alone, with chemo, or after chemo; also notes PARP inhibitor use after initial chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages discussion with the oncology team and lists specific questions to ask about testing, targets, drugs, benefits/side effects, treatment plan, and clinical trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that targeted therapy for pancreatic cancer involves using drugs to specifically target proteins, genes, or pathways of cancer cells, potentially causing less damage to normal cells compared to chemotherapy or radiation therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes targeting proteins/genes/pathways and notes potentially fewer side effects compared with traditional chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that while targeted therapy is an option, it is important to consider all potential treatment options, outcomes, and adverse events to make an informed decision.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises discussing benefits and side effects, how targeted therapy fits into the overall plan, and considering clinical trials, supporting informed decision-making.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention examples of targeted therapies, such as Dabrafenib + trametinib (if BRAF V600E mutation-positive), Entrectinib, Larotrectinib, Repotrectinib (if NTRK gene fusion-positive), Selpercatinib (if RET gene fusion-positive), Rucaparib (for germline or somatic BRCA1/2 or PALB2 mutations), Olaparib (only for germline BRCA1/2 mutations), Adagrasib (if KRAS G12C mutation-positive), Sotorasib (if KRAS G12C mutation-positive), Erdafitinib (if FGFR genetic alterations), Fam-trastuzumab deruxtecan-nxki (if HER2 positive [IHC3+ or IHC2+ with FISH HER2 amplified]) Zenocutuzumab-zbco (if NRG1 gene fusion-positive).
criterion_scores.justification: Includes several listed examples: larotrectinib, entrectinib (NTRK), olaparib and rucaparib (PARP inhibitors), and sotorasib and adagrasib (KRAS G12C).

criterion_scores.description: Negative points if targeted therapies are discussed that are not approved for pancreatic cancer, such as osimertinib, regorafenib, mTOR inhibitors.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention prohibited examples (osimertinib, regorafenib, mTOR inhibitors); no penalty applied.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing integrative medicine with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states multiple times to discuss with the oncology team: 'Always discuss any and all integrative... therapies with your loved one's oncology team before starting them,' and 'Lead with the Oncology Team.'

criterion_scores.description: The response states integrative medicine is not as effective as standard of care treatments for pancreatic cancer like chemotherapy, radiation, surgery, and targeted therapies.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly differentiates roles: 'Integrative therapies are not used to cure pancreatic cancer' and 'It does not replace conventional care,' emphasizing that abandoning standard treatments is dangerous.

criterion_scores.description: The response states integrative medicine can be a helpful adjunct to standard of care treatments for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes adjunctive use: 'This approach uses evidence-based complementary therapies alongside standard conventional medical treatments' and details benefits for symptom management and quality of life.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines integrative medicine.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a clear definition: integrative medicine uses evidence-based complementary therapies alongside conventional treatments to manage symptoms and support the whole person.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides examples of integrative medicine interventions.
criterion_scores.justification: Gives multiple examples: meditation, mindfulness, yoga, tai chi, guided imagery, music/art therapy, acupuncture, oncology massage, reflexology, and nutrition counseling.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends telling the patient’s oncologist if they plan to include integrative medicine interventions into their care plan.
criterion_scores.justification: States to consult the oncology team before starting any integrative/alternative therapies and to initiate the conversation with the care team.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends telling the patient’s oncologist about all supplements they are taking.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicit directive: 'Do not give your loved one any new vitamin, herb, or supplement without getting explicit approval from their oncologist.'

criterion_scores.description: The response states some supplements may interact with the treatments being prescribed for their pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes interactions and mechanisms: high-dose antioxidants may interfere with chemo/radiation; herbal supplements can affect drug metabolism (e.g., St. John’s Wort); 'immune-boosting' supplements may interact with immunotherapies.

criterion_scores.description: The response states there is data to support some integrative medicine interventions for specific uses.
criterion_scores.justification: States 'There is strong evidence that acupuncture can help manage chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting' and that some therapies are 'often supported by evidence' for symptom management.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that safety concerns and risks related to integrative medicine approaches are heightened with self-prescription or use of non-standardized products.
criterion_scores.justification: Warns against self-prescribing ('Do not give... any... supplement without explicit approval'), advises using qualified practitioners, and flags red-flag products ('secret' or proprietary), emphasizing heightened risk without professional oversight.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing integrative medicine with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises open communication with the oncology team multiple times, including 'Talk to the Oncology Team' and 'Communicate EVERYTHING with the Oncology Team.'

criterion_scores.description: The response states integrative medicine is not as effective as standard of care treatments for pancreatic cancer like chemotherapy, radiation, surgery, and targeted therapies.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states integrative medicine is NOT an alternative to conventional treatment and 'is not a cure,' establishing it is not a substitute for standard-of-care efficacy.

criterion_scores.description: The response states integrative medicine can be a helpful adjunct to standard of care treatments for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes integrative medicine as supporting conventional care by managing side effects and improving tolerance, emphasizing adjunctive use.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines integrative medicine.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a clear definition: combining evidence-based conventional treatments with complementary therapies to treat the whole person.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides examples of integrative medicine interventions.
criterion_scores.justification: Offers multiple examples: mind-body therapies, nutritional support, physical activity, acupuncture, massage, and herbs/supplements.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends telling the patient’s oncologist if they plan to include integrative medicine interventions into their care plan.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes informing the oncology team about all complementary therapies and coordinating care; includes a dedicated section on communication.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends telling the patient’s oncologist about all supplements they are taking.

criterion_scores.description: The response states some supplements may interact with the treatments being prescribed for their pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response states there is data to support some integrative medicine interventions for specific uses.
