criterion_scores.description: The response states cryotherapy is a procedure that uses metal instruments cooled to subzero temperatures in order to kill tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes use of cryoprobes (needle-like instruments) cooled with argon/liquid nitrogen to −100°C to −190°C to destroy tumor cells. While not explicitly saying 'metal,' the description of cryoprobes and mechanism clearly meets the intent.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that cryotherapy (also called cryoablation) is a minimally invasive locoregional treatment that destroys tumor tissue by freezing it, typically using probes inserted through the skin (percutaneously) or intraoperatively under imaging guidance.
criterion_scores.justification: Calls it cryoablation, labels it minimally invasive, explains imaging guidance (CT/ultrasound), and describes percutaneous insertion of probes to freeze/destroy the tumor.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the decision to use cryotherapy involves the cancer’s size, location, proximity to other organs, among other things.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions inoperability due to involvement with major vessels, accessibility without endangering nearby organs, and explicitly references tumor size and location in questions to ask clinicians.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing the benefits and risks of this procedure with the patient’s healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages meeting with oncologist and interventional radiologist and suggests asking about benefits, specific risks, success rates, recovery, and alternatives.

criterion_scores.description: The response states cryotherapy may be used in conjunction with other treatment modalities like chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes emerging research combining cryotherapy with immunotherapy and prompts discussion of how it fits with chemotherapy or radiation.

criterion_scores.description: The response states cryotherapy is not typically used to cure cancer but may be used to debulk tumors that are not operable.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states it is not typically a cure and describes its use for debulking in locally advanced, inoperable tumors.

criterion_scores.description: The response states not all patients benefit from cryotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly state that not all patients benefit; discusses candidacy and limitations but does not make this point directly.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that in pancreatic cancer, cryotherapy is not a standard first-line therapy but is considered for patients with unresectable, locally advanced, or metastatic disease who are not candidates for surgical resection or have failed systemic therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: States it is not a standard first-line therapy and discusses consideration for inoperable (unresectable) and locally advanced disease. Although it does not mention metastatic disease or failed systemic therapy, it meets the core requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that its primary role is palliative, aiming to reduce tumor burden, alleviate pain, and potentially improve quality of life and local disease control.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly frames cryotherapy’s goals as palliative with emphasis on pain relief, debulking/tumor control, and improving quality of life.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises a thorough discussion with the oncology team and a multidisciplinary team.

criterion_scores.description: The response states cryotherapy is a procedure that uses metal instruments cooled to subzero temperatures in order to kill tumors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that cryotherapy (also called cryoablation) is a minimally invasive locoregional treatment that destroys tumor tissue by freezing it, typically using probes inserted through the skin (percutaneously) or intraoperatively under imaging guidance.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the decision to use cryotherapy involves the cancer’s size, location, proximity to other organs, among other things.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that its primary role is palliative, aiming to reduce tumor burden, alleviate pain, and potentially improve quality of life and local disease control.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response states CA 19-9 is the tumor marker most commonly used to track disease status in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States CA 19-9 is the most well-known and widely used tumor marker for pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response states other tumor markers, like CEA and CA 125, are less reliable than CA 19-9 for disease monitoring in pancreatic cancer and are used more frequently in other gastrointestinal or genitourinary cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes CEA is less specific/sensitive than CA 19-9 and that CEA is commonly used in colorectal and other GI cancers; identifies CA 125 as primarily an ovarian cancer marker and not routinely checked in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response states tumor markers may be used to monitor the course of disease in patients with pancreatic cancer, along with imaging studies.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes use of markers to monitor treatment/progression and references changes relative to CT scans, implying use alongside imaging.

criterion_scores.description: The response states tumor markers are not reliable markers of disease in all patients with pancreatic cancer, as not all tumors secrete the markers.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that 5–10% of people (Lewis antigen negative) do not produce CA 19-9, indicating markers are not reliable for all patients.

criterion_scores.description: The response states circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) is an emerging technology aimed at detecting early cancer progression and recurrence.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes ctDNA as a liquid biopsy used to detect mutations, monitor treatment response, and detect MRD/recurrence, sometimes earlier than imaging.

criterion_scores.description: The response states circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) is not FDA approved for disease monitoring in pancreatic cancer and remains experimental.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not state ctDNA is not FDA approved for monitoring pancreatic cancer or that it remains experimental.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that CEA is elevated in 30-60% of pancreatic cancer cases and is particularly useful in Lewis-negative patients who do not secrete CA19-9.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions 30–60% elevation rate but does not state that CEA is particularly useful in Lewis-negative patients.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that both CEA and CA125 have demonstrated value for diagnosis, prognosis, and monitoring, especially when CA19-9 is not informative. CA125, when combined with CA19-9, improves diagnostic accuracy and is associated with tumor burden and metastatic disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not discuss diagnostic/prognostic value of CEA/CA125, their use when CA19-9 is not informative, combination improving diagnostic accuracy, or CA125’s association with tumor burden/metastasis.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response states CA 19-9 is the tumor marker most commonly used to track disease status in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States that CA 19-9 is the most established and commonly used tumor marker for pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

criterion_scores.description: The response states other tumor markers, like CEA and CA 125, are less reliable than CA 19-9 for disease monitoring in pancreatic cancer and are used more frequently in other gastrointestinal or genitourinary cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes CEA is less sensitive/specific than CA 19-9 and CA 125 is primarily a marker for ovarian cancer; also mentions CEA’s role in colorectal cancer. This conveys they are less reliable for pancreatic cancer monitoring and more commonly used in other cancers.

criterion_scores.description: The response states tumor markers may be used to monitor the course of disease in patients with pancreatic cancer, along with imaging studies.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions CA 19-9 tracking and emphasizes interpreting tumor markers in the context of imaging results and clinical condition.

criterion_scores.description: The response states tumor markers are not reliable markers of disease in all patients with pancreatic cancer, as not all tumors secrete the markers.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that not all patients produce CA 19-9 and highlights limitations and false elevations.

criterion_scores.description: The response states circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) is an emerging technology aimed at detecting early cancer progression and recurrence.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes ctDNA as emerging, with uses including early detection, monitoring response, detecting minimal residual disease (post-surgery), and indicating resistance/progression.

criterion_scores.description: The response states circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) is not FDA approved for disease monitoring in pancreatic cancer and remains experimental.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that CEA is elevated in 30-60% of pancreatic cancer cases and is particularly useful in Lewis-negative patients who do not secrete CA19-9.

criterion_scores.description: The response states hair loss from chemotherapy is a common and distressing side effect in patients undergoing treatment for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States hair loss concern is common and impacts self-esteem and emotional well-being in the context of pancreatic cancer chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response states other chemotherapy regimens or immunotherapy or targeted therapy cause hair loss at lower rates or not at all.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes gemcitabine alone typically causes mild thinning if any, indicating lower rates with certain regimens.

criterion_scores.description: The response states many cancer patients wear hats or wigs to help with appearances and self-esteem.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends wigs, scarves, hats, turbans, and beanies as appearance aids.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends cancer support groups.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages talking with a support group as part of emotional support.

criterion_scores.description: The response reports expected timelines for hair loss after starting chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: States hair loss usually starts 2 to 4 weeks after the first chemotherapy treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that the severity and risk of hair loss is higher with multi-agent and taxane-containing protocols, and female patients are at increased risk.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes higher risk with taxane-containing and multi-agent regimens but does not mention increased risk in female patients.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that most cases of hair loss are reversible, with regrowth expected within 3-6 months after cessation of chemotherapy, but persistent or permanent alopecia can occur, especially after repeated or high-dose regimens.
criterion_scores.justification: States regrowth occurs weeks to months after chemotherapy but does not specify 3–6 months or mention potential for persistent/permanent alopecia.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that eyebrow and eyelash loss may also be seen.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions loss of eyebrows and eyelashes.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that topical minoxidil may aid regrowth post-chemotherapy, though evidence for prevention is limited.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of topical minoxidil.

criterion_scores.description: Defines oligometastatic disease in pancreatic cancer as a state where the cancer has spread to a limited number of sites, typically involving a single organ (e.g., liver or lung) and a small number of lesions, commonly defined as ≤3 to ≤5 metastases.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly explains that oligometastatic means a limited number of metastases, explicitly citing 1–5 lesions and giving organ examples (liver, lungs). Although it mentions one or two organs, it conveys the typical limited-site concept with correct lesion count.

criterion_scores.description: Recommends discussing this with the patient’s healthcare team or oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a dedicated section with specific questions to ask the oncologist and encourages ongoing discussions with the medical team.

criterion_scores.description: Discusses the potential impact oligometastatic disease may have on treatment options, including the possibility of aggressive multimodal therapy such as systemic chemotherapy followed by local treatments like surgery, ablation, or stereotactic radiotherapy, if there is a good response to initial therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes a strategy of systemic chemotherapy first, then local ablative options (surgery, SBRT, ablation) if disease is controlled, matching the rubric.

criterion_scores.description: Contrasts oligometastatic disease to localized disease and widespread metastatic disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly frames oligometastatic disease as an in-between state—more advanced than localized to the pancreas but not widely disseminated.

criterion_scores.description: Mentions that patients with oligometastatic disease have the potential for an improved prognosis compared to widespread metastatic disease.
criterion_scores.justification: While it notes potential for extended survival with aggressive treatment, it does not explicitly state improved prognosis compared to widespread metastatic disease.

criterion_scores.description: Defines oligometastatic disease in pancreatic cancer as a state where the cancer has spread to a limited number of sites, typically involving a single organ and a small number of lesions (≤3 to ≤5).
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly explains that oligometastatic means a limited number of metastases, explicitly citing 'typically 1–5 distinct spots' and provides examples (liver or lung). While it does not explicitly say 'single organ,' the examples imply this typical pattern. The definition aligns with common thresholds (≤3–5 lesions).

criterion_scores.description: Recommends discussing this with the patient’s healthcare team or oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly encourages discussion with the oncologist and care team and even provides specific questions to ask.

criterion_scores.description: Discusses the potential impact on treatment options, including aggressive multimodal therapy such as systemic chemotherapy followed by local treatments like surgery, ablation, or stereotactic radiotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes the shift to aggressive, local treatments alongside systemic therapy and lists surgery, SBRT, and ablation, noting combination with chemotherapy and multidisciplinary evaluation. This satisfies the criterion for multimodal approaches.

criterion_scores.description: Contrasts oligometastatic disease to localized disease and widespread metastatic disease.
criterion_scores.justification: The response provides a clear 'spectrum' comparison among localized, oligometastatic, and widespread metastatic disease.

criterion_scores.description: Mentions that patients with oligometastatic disease have the potential for an improved prognosis compared to widespread metastatic disease.
criterion_scores.justification: It states potential for 'better outcomes,' including longer survival compared to widespread metastatic disease, improved quality of life, and rare cases of long-term remission.

criterion_scores.description: The response states it is common for patients to have low blood counts due to chemotherapy used in the treatment of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states, 'Yes, it is extremely common for pancreatic cancer treatments to be delayed due to low blood counts,' and ties this to chemotherapy side effects.

criterion_scores.description: The response states treatment delays due to low blood counts are enacted to ensure the patient’s safety.
criterion_scores.justification: Affirms delays are a 'crucial safety protocol' to allow marrow recovery and avoid infection, severe anemia, and bleeding.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the oncologist may recommend dose reducing the chemotherapy or changing to a different treatment if the blood counts remain low.
criterion_scores.justification: States the oncologist may 'reduce the dose of the chemotherapy or change the treatment schedule.' Dose reduction is explicitly mentioned, satisfying the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response gives examples of chemotherapy known to cause low blood counts.
criterion_scores.justification: No specific pancreatic cancer chemotherapy regimens or drugs (e.g., FOLFIRINOX, gemcitabine, nab-paclitaxel) are named.

criterion_scores.description: The response lists the different types of low blood counts that may impact treatment, including anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, and low total white blood cell count, and explains why these cells are important in layman’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia in lay terms, but does not explicitly include 'low total white blood cell count' as a separate item, which the criterion requires.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the oncologist may prescribe an injection medication (e.g., G-CSF) to help increase the neutrophil count.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions G-CSF injections (Neupogen/Neulasta) to stimulate white blood cell production.

criterion_scores.description: The response states if the red blood cell or platelet counts get too low, the oncologist may order a transfusion of red blood cells or platelets to keep these at safe levels.
criterion_scores.justification: States that blood or platelet transfusions may be given for severe anemia or thrombocytopenia.

criterion_scores.description: The response instructs the patient to seek immediate medical evaluation if they have low blood counts and experience fever, chest pain, shortness of breath, leg swelling, blood in the urine, blood in the stool, or other uncontrollable bleeding.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that 'A fever during neutropenia is a medical emergency' but does not instruct immediate evaluation for chest pain, shortness of breath, leg swelling, blood in urine/stool, or uncontrollable bleeding.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends ensuring good nutrition to ensure the bone marrow can produce the required blood cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends a well-balanced diet rich in protein and calories and consulting an oncology dietitian.

criterion_scores.description: The response must strongly recommend consulting with an oncologist or care team, providing specific questions or topics to discuss.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages communication with the medical team and provides specific questions about counts, targets, supportive medications, and warning signs.

criterion_scores.description: The response states it is common for patients to have low blood counts due to chemotherapy used in the treatment of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response opens by stating this is a very common issue, especially when chemotherapy is involved, and explains chemotherapy-induced myelosuppression.

criterion_scores.description: The response states treatment delays due to low blood counts are enacted to ensure the patient’s safety.
criterion_scores.justification: A dedicated section ('Why Treatment Delays Are Necessary') explicitly states delays are for patient safety, citing infection and bleeding risks.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the oncologist may recommend dose reducing the chemotherapy or changing to a different treatment if the blood counts remain low.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions 'Dose Adjustments' and 'Treatment Regimen Changes' if current therapy leads to persistent low counts.

criterion_scores.description: The response gives examples of chemotherapy known to cause low blood counts.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it discusses chemotherapy generally, it provides no specific examples (e.g., FOLFIRINOX, gemcitabine, nab-paclitaxel) known to cause cytopenias.

criterion_scores.description: The response lists the different types of low blood counts that may impact treatment, including anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, and low total white blood cell count, and explains why these cells are important in layman’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly lists neutropenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia with lay explanations of risks (infection, fatigue, bleeding). It also references 'white blood cell counts are too low' and explains infection danger, covering low total WBC concept.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the oncologist may prescribe an injection medication (e.g., G-CSF) to help increase the neutrophil count.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends growth factors such as G-CSF (Neupogen, Neulasta) to stimulate white blood cell (neutrophil) production.

criterion_scores.description: The response states if the red blood cell or platelet counts get too low, the oncologist may order a transfusion of red blood cells or platelets to keep these at safe levels.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states blood transfusions can be used for severe anemia and platelet transfusions for thrombocytopenia.

criterion_scores.description: The response instructs the patient to seek immediate medical evaluation if they have low blood counts and experience fever, chest pain, shortness of breath, leg swelling, blood in the urine, blood in the stool, or other uncontrollable bleeding.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises reporting fever, chills, unusual bleeding, or severe fatigue to the care team but does not explicitly instruct immediate evaluation nor list chest pain, shortness of breath, leg swelling, hematuria, or blood in stool.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends ensuring good nutrition to ensure the bone marrow can produce the required blood cells.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends 'Nutritional Support' including adequate nutrition and pancreatic enzyme replacement to aid recovery and blood cell production.

criterion_scores.description: The response must strongly recommend consulting with an oncologist or care team, providing specific questions or topics to discuss.
criterion_scores.justification: It urges communication with the medical team and suggests specific topics: current counts, risks, plans to resume treatment, and strategies to support count recovery at home.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises discussing with the father's oncology team in the disclaimer and again at the end.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains hyperthermia treatment for cancer in layman’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a clear, accessible explanation of what hyperthermia is, how it works, session experience, and side effects.

criterion_scores.description: The response specifies that hyperthermia treatment involves heating tumor tissue to a temperature range of 39-43°C to enhance the cytotoxic effects of chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions 40–44°C (not 39–43°C) and sensitization to chemo/radiation; the required temperature range is not stated as specified.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions all three delivery methods: regional (including ‘deep regional’), intraoperative, and whole-body hyperthermia.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes local, regional, and whole-body hyperthermia but does not mention intraoperative hyperthermia or specify 'deep regional.'

criterion_scores.description: The response reviews potential benefits and risks of hyperthermia treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers benefits (improved response, survival, QoL, enhanced oxygenation/immune effects) and risks (skin irritation, blisters, discomfort).

criterion_scores.description: The response states hyperthermia is not an effective alternative to standard of care treatment for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Positions hyperthermia as adjunctive and investigational but does not explicitly state it is not an effective alternative to standard care.

criterion_scores.description: The response states hyperthermia is not a standard first-line therapy for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states it is not a standard, first-line therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response states there is not robust evidence for the use of hyperthermia treatment in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that larger randomized controlled trials are still needed and it is not standard of care, indicating evidence is not robust.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that hyperthermia is used in pancreatic cancer as an adjunct to standard chemoradiotherapy for patients with locally advanced, unresectable, or metastatic disease, especially when conventional therapies have limited efficacy or are refractory.
criterion_scores.justification: While it describes adjunctive use, it does not specifically mention locally advanced/unresectable/metastatic or refractory settings, nor explicitly 'chemoradiotherapy.'

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that adding hyperthermia to chemoradiotherapy may improve overall response rates and median survival compared to standard therapy alone, with acceptable safety profiles.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions possible improvements when added to chemotherapy and/or radiation with tolerable side effects, but does not specifically address addition to chemoradiotherapy versus standard therapy alone.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that the quality of evidence for hyperthermia is limited, it remains investigational, and there are ongoing trials evaluating its efficacy and optimal integration into multimodal treatment regimens.
criterion_scores.justification: States it is investigational and more RCTs are needed, but does not explicitly say evidence quality is limited and does not mention ongoing trials evaluating efficacy and integration.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define stage IV pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not explicitly define stage IV as metastatic disease with distant spread (e.g., to liver, peritoneum, lungs).

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that the disease is not curable.
criterion_scores.justification: While it discusses controlling growth and quality of life, it never explicitly states that stage IV pancreatic cancer is not curable.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include the goal of treatment is to control the cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states the goal is to control the cancer's growth and extend life.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include the goal of treatment to improve symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: It emphasizes symptom management and maintaining quality of life throughout.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the cornerstone of treatment for stage IV pancreatic cancer is systemic chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly calls chemotherapy the cornerstone of care for stage IV disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include chemotherapy regimens listed in NCCN guidelines (version 2.2025) for treatment of metastatic pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists FOLFIRINOX and gemcitabine plus nab-paclitaxel, which are NCCN-recommended first-line regimens for metastatic disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should discuss that clinical trials are another option.
criterion_scores.justification: There is a dedicated section on clinical trials with concrete steps and resources.

criterion_scores.justification: It discusses PARP inhibitors for BRCA mutations, pembrolizumab for MSI-H/dMMR, and mentions NTRK and KRAS G12C targets.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend the tumor have genetic testing.
criterion_scores.justification: It strongly recommends comprehensive biomarker/genomic testing as soon as possible and provides questions to ask the oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that some chemotherapy can have negative effects on the heart.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states, 'Some chemotherapy drugs can weaken the heart muscle... This is called cardiomyopathy,' and 'The treatments... particularly chemotherapy... can affect the heart in several ways.'

criterion_scores.description: The response specifically mentions that 5-fluorouracil (or “5-FU”) can harm the heart.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly notes, 'One of the drugs in this combination, 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU), is particularly known for its potential to cause cardiotoxicity.'

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends monitoring for shortness of breath.
criterion_scores.justification: Under 'Monitoring at Home,' it lists 'Shortness of Breath (Dyspnea)' with guidance on what to watch for.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends monitoring for chest pain.
criterion_scores.justification: It includes 'Chest Pain, Tightness, or Discomfort' and labels it an emergency with instructions to call 911.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends monitoring for fast heart rate.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists 'Heart Palpitations' and describes feelings of the heart 'racing, fluttering, pounding, or skipping beats.'

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends monitoring for dizziness.
criterion_scores.justification: It includes 'Dizziness, Lightheadedness, or Fainting' as symptoms to watch and report.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends monitoring for unusual fatigue.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists 'Extreme Fatigue or Weakness' and specifies watching for a sudden increase or disproportionate exhaustion.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends discussing any new symptom with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises tracking 'any new or worsening symptoms' but directs contacting the team only 'if you notice any of the following' listed symptoms; it does not explicitly recommend discussing any new symptom in general.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends discussing any concerning symptom with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: It states, 'Contact her oncology nurse or doctor immediately if you notice any of the following' and emphasizes communicating with the medical team about concerning signs.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that electrocardiograms can be used to monitor the heart.
criterion_scores.justification: Under 'Baseline Heart Assessment,' it includes 'An Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG).'

criterion_scores.description: The response states that echocardiogram can be used to monitor heart function.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends 'An Echocardiogram (Echo)' with LVEF measurement and suggests 'Repeat Echocardiograms' during treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that blood pressure can be used to monitor the heart.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists 'Regular Blood Pressure and Heart Rate Checks' at clinic visits and at home monitoring with an automatic cuff.

criterion_scores.description: The response specifically mentions that capecitabine can harm the heart.
criterion_scores.justification: Capecitabine is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response specifically mentions that some targeted therapies can harm the heart.
criterion_scores.justification: Targeted therapies are not discussed as a source of cardiotoxicity.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that pancreatic cancer treatments can cause at least three cardiac issues: heart failure, arrhythmias, hypertension, ischemia, or cardiomyopathy.
criterion_scores.justification: It names cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias, hypertension, and coronary artery spasm leading to angina/heart attack (ischemia).

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly states that the risk of cardiac side effects is higher in patients with preexisting cardiovascular conditions or those receiving specific agents such as anthracyclines or fluoropyrimidines.
criterion_scores.justification: While it notes 5-FU can be cardiotoxic, it does not state that risk is higher in patients with preexisting cardiovascular conditions nor compare risk among specific agents.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly recommends baseline cardiac risk assessment and regular monitoring with echocardiography, cardiac biomarkers, and clinical evaluation for early/asymptomatic cardiac dysfunction.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends baseline echo and ECG, repeat echocardiograms, biomarkers (BNP/NT-proBNP, troponin), and clinical checks (BP, HR, physical exams), noting biomarkers as 'early warning' signs.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly references recommendations from the ACC and/or ASCO about pretherapy evaluation and ongoing surveillance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe PARP inhibitors as a class of targeted agents that block the PARP enzyme, which is involved in repairing single-strand DNA breaks.
criterion_scores.justification: The response accurately explains that PARP inhibitors block the PARP enzyme, describes PARP’s role in repairing single-strand DNA breaks, and frames them as targeted therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that PARP inhibitors can be used in advanced pancreatic cancer when there is a germline mutation in a BRCA gene.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states that the primary indication in pancreatic cancer is for patients with germline BRCA1/2 mutations and contextualizes use in metastatic disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that PARP inhibitors are used as maintenance therapy in patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer who have a germline BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation and whose cancer has not progressed after at least 16 weeks of first-line platinum-based chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly describes maintenance use in metastatic pancreatic cancer with germline BRCA mutations after a response/stable disease on platinum-based chemotherapy for at least 16 weeks.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that comprehensive germline testing for BRCA mutations is recommended for all patients with pancreatic cancer to identify those eligible for this targeted approach.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that all patients with pancreatic cancer are recommended to undergo genetic testing to identify mutations such as BRCA1/2.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the American Society of Clinical Oncology specifically recommends olaparib, based on the POLO trial, which demonstrated a significant improvement in progression-free survival compared to placebo, without compromising quality of life.
criterion_scores.justification: Although olaparib is mentioned, there is no reference to ASCO recommendations, the POLO trial, progression-free survival benefit, or quality of life findings.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that other PARP inhibitors and combination strategies are under investigation, but their use remains investigational at this time. Based on the NCCN Guidelines Version 2.2025: Principles of Systemic Therapy for Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma (Metastatic Disease, First-Line Therapy) across performance status groups. For Good PS (0–1), preferred regimens include FOLFIRINOX (category 1 or modified FOLFIRINOX), Gemcitabine + albumin-bound paclitaxel (category 1), and NALIRIFOX (category 1). For patients with BRCA1/2 or PALB2 mutations, preferred options are FOLFIRINOX (category 1 or modified FOLFIRINOX) and Gemcitabine + cisplatin (category 1). Other recommended regimens include Gemcitabine (category 1), Gemcitabine + erlotinib (category 1), Gemcitabine + capecitabine, Gemcitabine + albumin-bound paclitaxel + cisplatin, Fluoropyrimidine + oxaliplatin, CapeOx (category 2B), OFF (category 2B), and GTX (category 2B). For Intermediate PS (2), preferred regimens include Gemcitabine + albumin-bound paclitaxel (category 1), Capecitabine, Gemcitabine, 5-FU + leucovorin + oxaliplatin (FOLFOX), 5-FU + leucovorin + irinotecan (FOLFIRI), and CapeOx. For Poor PS (3), Palliative and best supportive care is recommended, though options include Capecitabine (category 2B), continuous infusion 5-FU (category 2B), and Gemcitabine (standard or fixed-dose-rate infusion). Across all PS groups, therapies useful in certain circumstances include targeted agents: Entrectinib, Larotrectinib, and Repotrectinib (for NTRK gene fusion–positive tumors); Pembrolizumab (for MSI-H, dMMR, or TMB-H ≥10 mut/Mb); Selpercatinib (for RET gene fusion–positive tumors); and Dabrafenib + trametinib (for BRAF V600E mutation–positive cases). The guidelines note that all regimens are category 2A unless otherwise indicated, and patients with poor PS derive marginal benefit from systemic therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not discuss investigational status of other PARP inhibitors/combination strategies or reference NCCN-based first-line regimen frameworks.

criterion_scores.description: Defines ctDNA as DNA from cancer cells/tumors found in blood and notes use as biomarker for diagnosis, monitoring, or recurrence

criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly includes a section on monitoring treatment response, noting ctDNA levels decrease with effective therapy and may rise if ineffective.

criterion_scores.description: Mentions that copy-number changes may be more difficult to assess in cfDNA, and fusion testing may be more limited in common cfDNA tests currently used.

criterion_scores.description: Mentions that ctDNA may miss low-level cancers or not detect all mutations, and there may be false negative or false positive results.
criterion_scores.justification: It states ctDNA is not 100% sensitive and may not detect ctDNA when tumors are small or not shedding, which corresponds to missed low-level disease and false negatives.

criterion_scores.description: Mentions that not all hospitals offer ctDNA testing and that not all insurances cover them.
criterion_scores.justification: It suggests asking about insurance coverage but does not state that availability varies by hospital or that coverage is not universal.

criterion_scores.justification: Names larotrectinib and entrectinib and explains they are tumor-agnostic for NTRK fusions.

criterion_scores.justification: Mentions sotorasib (and adagrasib) for KRAS G12C with ongoing clinical trials in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that routine molecular tumor profiling is now feasible and recommended for all patients with pancreatic cancer, regardless of stage or surgical eligibility. Based on the NCCN Guidelines Version 2.2025, Clinical Presentation and Workup pathway for pancreatic adenocarcinoma, stating that patients with clinical suspicion of pancreatic cancer or evidence of dilated pancreatic/bile duct should undergo pancreatic protocol CT or MRI (abdomen) for evaluation. A multidisciplinary consultation is recommended after imaging. Workup includes chest and pelvis CT, endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS), MRI for indeterminate liver lesions, PET/CT or PET/MRI for high-risk features, and ERCP with stent placement if biliary obstruction is present. Laboratory evaluation should include liver function tests and baseline CA 19-9 after biliary drainage. If diagnosis is confirmed, perform genetic testing for inherited mutations. For metastatic disease, confirm with biopsy from a metastatic site, and perform molecular profiling of tumor tissue and complete staging with chest and pelvis CT. Depending on findings, categorize as resectable (PANC-2), borderline resectable (PANC-4), locally advanced (PANC-5), or metastatic disease (PANC-10). If no mass or diagnosis is confirmed, refer to a high-volume center for evaluation.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not reference NCCN guidelines, universal recommendation for profiling, or the detailed imaging/workup pathway.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that approximately 20–28% of patients have actionable findings, and those who receive matched therapies based on tumor profiling have significantly improved progression-free and overall survival compared to those who do not.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of actionable rate percentages or survival benefits with matched therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that actionable alterations include BRCA1/2 mutations, NTRK, BRAF, FGFR2, RET, NRG1, and ALK fusions, and mismatch repair deficiency (dMMR/MSI-H).
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions BRCA1/2, NTRK, and dMMR/MSI-H, but omits BRAF, FGFR2, RET, NRG1, and ALK fusions.

Based on the NCCN Guidelines Version 2.2025, Clinical Presentation and Workup pathway for pancreatic adenocarcinoma, stating that patients with clinical suspicion of pancreatic cancer or evidence of dilated pancreatic/bile duct should undergo pancreatic protocol CT or MRI (abdomen) for evaluation. A multidisciplinary consultation is recommended after imaging. Workup includes chest and pelvis CT, endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS), MRI for indeterminate liver lesions, PET/CT or PET/MRI for high-risk features, and ERCP with stent placement if biliary obstruction is present. Laboratory evaluation should include liver function tests and baseline CA 19-9 after biliary drainage. If diagnosis is confirmed, perform genetic testing for inherited mutations. For metastatic disease, confirm with biopsy from a metastatic site, and perform molecular profiling of tumor tissue and complete staging with chest and pelvis CT. Depending on findings, categorize as resectable (PANC-2), borderline resectable (PANC-4), locally advanced (PANC-5), or metastatic disease (PANC-10). If no mass or diagnosis is confirmed, refer to a high-volume center for evaluation.

criterion_scores.justification: Advises requesting a formal denial letter from the insurance company that states the specific reason for denial and outlines the appeal process, and emphasizes record-keeping for calls.

criterion_scores.description: The person should file an appeal as an option to remedy the denial.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides detailed steps for initiating internal appeals, writing a formal appeal letter, and requesting an expedited appeal.

criterion_scores.description: The person should work with their oncology team to help with the denial.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends working closely with the oncologist/care team for a letter of medical necessity, peer-to-peer review, and submission of supporting documentation.

criterion_scores.description: The person should work with their oncology team to understand the denial.
criterion_scores.justification: While it explains reasons for denial and advises getting the denial letter, it does not explicitly instruct working with the oncology team to understand or interpret the denial.

criterion_scores.description: Patient assistance programs should be considered.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends manufacturer patient assistance programs and co-pay assistance programs with examples and resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly defines prior authorization as a process in which insurers require approval before a medication is covered.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions prior authorization as 'the doctor didn't get approval before prescribing' but does not explicitly define it as insurer-required approval before coverage.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that prior authorization denials or delays are common in oncology care and mentions at least one impact.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not state that prior authorization denials/delays are common in oncology nor describe their impacts; it only notes urgency/time-sensitivity in general.

criterion_scores.description: The person should contact the oncologist to request a referral to a financial navigator or social worker.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions social workers, patient navigators, and financial counselors at cancer centers but does not explicitly instruct contacting the oncologist to request a referral.

criterion_scores.description: The appeal process involves submitting a formal appeal with supporting evidence.
criterion_scores.justification: Directs writing a formal appeal letter and attaching the physician's letter of medical necessity and all supporting medical documents.

criterion_scores.description: If appeals are unsuccessful, alternative access strategies should be pursued, such as patient assistance programs or manufacturer co-pay cards.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides alternative access strategies including manufacturer patient assistance programs, co-pay assistance, and clinical trials alongside appeals.

criterion_scores.description: The response names at least one patient advocacy organization that can help connect the user with resources.
criterion_scores.justification: Names Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN), Lustgarten Foundation, and American Cancer Society as resource organizations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing symptoms with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises to always speak with the oncology nurse or doctor; notes they can prescribe medications and adjust treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe common chemotherapy-related side effects, including dry skin.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes dryness/itching, hand-foot syndrome, and nail/cuticle changes as chemotherapy-related skin effects.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe management of dry skin, including using thick emollient creams.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends thick emollient creams/ointments (e.g., Eucerin, Aquaphor, CeraVe) with ceramides/urea.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe management of dry skin, including avoiding hot water.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises using lukewarm, not hot, water for bathing and showering.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe management of dry skin, including avoiding scrubbing the skin.
criterion_scores.justification: States to avoid harsh scrubbing and to gently pat the skin dry.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe common chemotherapy-related side effects, including hand-foot syndrome associated with certain chemotherapy drugs like capecitabine.
criterion_scores.justification: Hand-foot syndrome is described, but no explicit association with specific causative agents (e.g., capecitabine) is made.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include management of hand-foot syndrome, including the use of urea-based creams.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically recommends urea cream 10–20% for HFS.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include management of hand-foot syndrome, including the use of lanolin-based creams.
criterion_scores.justification: Lanolin-based creams are not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include management of hand-foot syndrome, including the use of supportive footwear.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises wearing loose, comfortable shoes and avoiding long walks to reduce pressure on feet.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include management of hand-foot syndrome, including the use of gloves at night.
criterion_scores.justification: Gloves at night are suggested for fissures from EGFR inhibitors, not specifically for HFS.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include management of hand-foot syndrome, including avoiding friction on affected areas.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises avoiding pressure and friction on hands and feet for HFS.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include management of hand-foot syndrome, including dose reduction of chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that the oncology team may adjust the dose or schedule for severe skin reactions, which applies to severe HFS.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe radiation dermatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes localized redness, swelling, itching, sunburn-like changes, peeling, and blistering within the radiation field.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe management of radiation dermatitis, including the use of creams approved by the radiation team.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises following the radiation oncology team's protocol and using only products approved by them; lists common options.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe management of radiation dermatitis, including avoiding sun exposure.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends protecting the treated skin from sun exposure.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly names at least one chemotherapy agent as a cause of skin changes, such as gemcitabine, FOLFIRINOX, or nab-paclitaxel.
criterion_scores.justification: Names gemcitabine, 5-FU, and FOLFIRINOX in the chemotherapy-related skin issues section.

criterion_scores.description: The response lists at least four distinct manifestations of chemotherapy-related skin changes, with at least two from the specified list.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions dryness/itching, HFS (redness, swelling, pain, peeling), nail brittleness/darkening/cracking, and paronychia—four or more distinct changes.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that skin changes may also be due to other causes such as infection, other medications, or unrelated skin disorders/systemic diseases.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises confirming that changes are not an allergic reaction or infection, acknowledging alternative causes.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that prevention of skin problems is important and should begin at or before therapy initiation.
criterion_scores.justification: While preventive measures are described, the timing (at or before therapy initiation) is not explicitly stated.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends using gentle, pH-balanced cleansers, regular moisturization, and broad-spectrum sun protection.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends pH-neutral gentle cleansers, frequent moisturizing with thick creams, and daily broad-spectrum SPF ≥30 sunscreen.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions prophylactic cooling measures during taxane infusions for hand-foot syndrome, supported by guidelines or evidence.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of prophylactic cooling during taxane infusions.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that correct identification of skin changes is important to ensure appropriate management and to avoid unnecessary discontinuation of effective cancer therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes distinguishing side effects from infection/allergy for appropriate management but does not mention avoiding unnecessary discontinuation of effective therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends hydration with emollients, topical corticosteroids, antihistamines, and oatmeal baths for dry skin and itch.
criterion_scores.justification: Suggests emollients, topical steroid creams, oral antihistamines, and oatmeal baths for pruritus/dryness.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that for acne-like rash, oral tetracyclines and topical steroids are effective treatments.
criterion_scores.justification: For EGFR-inhibitor rash, recommends oral doxycycline/minocycline (tetracyclines) and topical steroids.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that for hand-foot syndrome, urea creams, topical steroids, and cooling procedures are beneficial.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions urea creams and cooling for HFS but does not include topical steroids for HFS.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that mild immune-related rashes can be managed with topical corticosteroids, urea-containing creams, and antihistamines for pruritus.
criterion_scores.justification: Immune-related (checkpoint inhibitor) rash management is not discussed.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that severe immune-related rashes can be managed with systemic corticosteroids and, if refractory, immunomodulators, and that therapy interruption may be necessary for severe reactions.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of systemic corticosteroids, immunomodulators, or therapy interruption for severe immune-related rashes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing symptoms with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises regular communication with the oncology team, dermatologists, and nurses about any skin changes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe common chemotherapy-related side effects, including dry skin.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes dryness (xerosis), itching, rashes, hand-foot syndrome, nail changes, and photosensitivity as common treatment-related effects; specifically links dryness/itch to chemotherapies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe management of dry skin, including using thick emollient creams.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends thick, emollient-rich moisturizers (e.g., Aquaphor, Vaseline, Eucerin, CeraVe, Aveeno) applied frequently.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe management of dry skin, including avoiding hot water.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises using lukewarm water for showers/baths and avoiding hot water.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe management of dry skin, including avoiding scrubbing the skin.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises patting skin dry rather than rubbing and avoiding abrasive scrubs; also to avoid scrubbing/rubbing the radiated area.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe common chemotherapy-related side effects, including hand-foot syndrome associated with certain chemotherapy drugs like capecitabine.
criterion_scores.justification: Hand-foot syndrome is described with causative agents including capecitabine, 5-FU, gemcitabine, and liposomal irinotecan.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include management of hand-foot syndrome, including the use of urea-based creams.
criterion_scores.justification: No explicit mention of urea-based creams for hand-foot syndrome.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include management of hand-foot syndrome, including the use of lanolin-based creams.
criterion_scores.justification: Lanolin-based creams are not specifically recommended; products listed are not identified as lanolin-based.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include management of hand-foot syndrome, including the use of supportive footwear.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends wearing comfortable, loose-fitting shoes and cotton socks to reduce pressure.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include management of hand-foot syndrome, including the use of gloves at night.
criterion_scores.justification: Gloves at night are not mentioned; gloves are mentioned only for cooling during infusions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include management of hand-foot syndrome, including avoiding friction on affected areas.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends avoiding friction and pressure and limiting strenuous activities.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include management of hand-foot syndrome, including dose reduction of chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: States dose modification or interruption of chemotherapy may be necessary in severe cases.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe radiation dermatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes radiation dermatitis with redness, dryness, itch, peeling, blistering localized to the treated area.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe management of radiation dermatitis, including the use of creams approved by the radiation team.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises to use only products recommended by the radiation oncology team (e.g., Aquaphor, Biafine, aloe without fragrance).

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe management of radiation dermatitis, including avoiding sun exposure.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends avoiding sun exposure to the treated area indefinitely.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly names at least one chemotherapy agent as a cause of skin changes, such as gemcitabine, FOLFIRINOX, or nab-paclitaxel.
criterion_scores.justification: Names multiple agents (e.g., gemcitabine, 5-FU, paclitaxel, capecitabine, liposomal irinotecan, FOLFIRINOX components, erlotinib).

criterion_scores.description: The response lists at least four distinct manifestations of chemotherapy-related skin changes, with at least two from the specified list.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists dryness/itching, acneiform rash, maculopapular rash, hand-foot syndrome, nail changes, and photosensitivity (well over four, including multiple specified items).

criterion_scores.description: The response states that skin changes may also be due to other causes such as infection, other medications, or unrelated skin disorders/systemic diseases.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes pruritus may be related to liver issues (jaundice), and includes infections as a cause of skin findings; thus acknowledges non-treatment-damage etiologies.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that prevention of skin problems is important and should begin at or before therapy initiation.
criterion_scores.justification: While prevention is emphasized (e.g., 'Prevention (Crucial!)' for hand-foot syndrome), it does not explicitly state starting at or before therapy initiation.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends using gentle, pH-balanced cleansers, regular moisturization, and broad-spectrum sun protection.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends mild, pH-balanced cleansers; frequent application of emollient moisturizers; and daily broad-spectrum sunscreen (SPF 30+).

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions prophylactic cooling measures during taxane infusions for hand-foot syndrome, supported by guidelines or evidence.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions cooling socks/gloves during infusions but does not specify taxane infusions or cite guideline/evidence support.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that correct identification of skin changes is important to ensure appropriate management and to avoid unnecessary discontinuation of effective cancer therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly state that correct identification prevents unnecessary discontinuation; mentions dose modification for severity but not the avoidance of inappropriate discontinuation.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends hydration with emollients, topical corticosteroids, antihistamines, and oatmeal baths for dry skin and itch.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends frequent moisturizers (emollients), topical steroids, oral antihistamines, and colloidal oatmeal baths for pruritus.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that for acne-like rash, oral tetracyclines and topical steroids are effective treatments.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends oral doxycycline/minocycline (tetracyclines) and topical corticosteroids for acneiform rash due to EGFR inhibitors.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that for hand-foot syndrome, urea creams, topical steroids, and cooling procedures are beneficial.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes topical steroids and cooling measures but does not mention urea creams; criterion requires all elements.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that mild immune-related rashes can be managed with topical corticosteroids, urea-containing creams, and antihistamines for pruritus.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions topical corticosteroids and antihistamines for maculopapular rash but not urea-containing creams in the context of immune-related rash.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that severe immune-related rashes can be managed with systemic corticosteroids and, if refractory, immunomodulators, and that therapy interruption may be necessary for severe reactions.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes oral corticosteroids for severe rash but does not mention immunomodulators nor therapy interruption specifically for immune-related rashes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the tumor microenvironment.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines the TME as a complex ecosystem around the tumor, detailing its components (stroma, immune cells, vasculature) and functions, especially in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the tumor microenvironment in pancreatic cancer critically influences both treatment options and outcomes.
criterion_scores.justification: States that TME is key to why pancreatic cancer is difficult to treat and how it undermines chemo, immunotherapy, and radiation, thereby affecting options and outcomes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that the pancreatic cancer tumor microenvironment has a dense desmoplastic stroma which can act as a physical barrier.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions dense stroma/desmoplasia acting as a barrier and blocking drug penetration.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of stromal cells, including fibroblasts.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) as the builders of the stromal 'fortress walls.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of stromal cells, including pancreatic stellate cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Pancreatic stellate cells are not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of immune cells within the tumor microenvironment of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses regulatory T cells, tumor-associated macrophages, and their roles in suppressing effector T-cell function.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that the tumor microenvironment of pancreatic cancer can be immunosuppressive.
criterion_scores.justification: Characterizes the TME as creating an 'immune shield' and an 'immunologically cold' environment that suppresses immune attack.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the tumor microenvironment architecture creates physical and biochemical barriers that limit drug delivery, promote immune evasion, and drive resistance to chemotherapy, targeted therapy, and immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses physical barriers, hypoxia, immune evasion, and resistance to chemo and immunotherapy, but does not mention targeted therapy resistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that the tumor microenvironment of pancreatic cancer is implicated in drug resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly links TME features to reduced effectiveness/resistance of chemotherapy, immunotherapy, and radiation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that the tumor microenvironment of pancreatic cancer is implicated in metastasis.
criterion_scores.justification: States hypoxia makes cancer more aggressive and 'more likely to spread,' indicating a role in metastasis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that the tumor microenvironment of pancreatic cancer is implicated in relapse.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not discuss relapse or recurrence.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that drugs targeting the tumor microenvironment in pancreatic cancer have not yet shown benefit to patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions investigational strategies and trials but does not state that TME-targeted drugs have not yet shown patient benefit.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that many studies are underway evaluating the role of tumor microenvironment-targeted therapies in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes ongoing clinical trials and multiple investigational approaches targeting stroma and immune components.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that current and emerging treatment strategies increasingly focus on remodeling the tumor microenvironment to improve therapeutic efficacy.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes 'dismantling the fortress' and strategies such as stromal modulation, immune reprogramming, and vascular normalization to improve therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that locoregional therapies such as radiation and ablation may also alter the tumor microenvironment, increasing antigen presentation and immune response.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses radiation efficacy under hypoxia but does not mention TME alteration by radiation/ablation to increase antigen presentation or immune response.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the user discuss this case with an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages discussion with the oncology team, provides specific questions for the doctor, and includes a disclaimer to consult a qualified oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the tumor microenvironment.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines the tumor microenvironment as a complex ecosystem and details its components (cancer cells, stromal cells, immune cells, vasculature, ECM, signaling molecules).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the tumor microenvironment in pancreatic cancer critically influences both treatment options and outcomes.
criterion_scores.justification: States that the TME is a major roadblock to treatment and a critical factor in aggressiveness and resistance, implying impact on options and outcomes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that the pancreatic cancer tumor microenvironment has a dense desmoplastic stroma which can act as a physical barrier.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions desmoplasia, dense fibrous stroma, and describes it as a physical barrier that blocks drug penetration.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of stromal cells, including fibroblasts.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) and their role in ECM production and desmoplasia.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of stromal cells, including pancreatic stellate cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions stellate cells, their activation, and contribution to desmoplasia.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of immune cells within the tumor microenvironment of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Details MDSCs, TAMs, Tregs, exclusion/deactivation of effector T cells within the TME.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that the tumor microenvironment of pancreatic cancer can be immunosuppressive.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly describes the TME as immunosuppressive and explains mechanisms (suppressive cells, signaling).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that the tumor microenvironment architecture creates physical and biochemical barriers that limit drug delivery, promote immune evasion, and drive resistance to chemotherapy, targeted therapy, and immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers physical/biochemical barriers, limited drug delivery, immune suppression, and resistance to chemo and immunotherapy, but does not mention resistance to targeted therapy explicitly.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that the tumor microenvironment of pancreatic cancer is implicated in drug resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states that stromal interactions, hypoxia, and other TME features promote resistance to chemotherapy and immunotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that the tumor microenvironment of pancreatic cancer is implicated in metastasis.
criterion_scores.justification: No explicit mention of metastasis or TME’s role in metastatic spread.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that the tumor microenvironment of pancreatic cancer is implicated in relapse.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that many studies are underway evaluating the role of tumor microenvironment-targeted therapies in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States that disrupting/reprogramming the TME is a major focus of research and describes multiple investigational strategies, implying ongoing studies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that current and emerging treatment strategies increasingly focus on remodeling the tumor microenvironment to improve therapeutic efficacy.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly discusses strategies to disrupt or reprogram the TME to improve efficacy, including stroma-targeting, immunomodulation, and vessel normalization.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that locoregional therapies such as radiation and ablation may also alter the tumor microenvironment, increasing antigen presentation and immune response.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the user discuss this case with an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages discussion with the father's medical team, which reasonably includes the oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that antibiotics are reserved for documented secondary bacterial infections.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cells that acquire mutations that can go on to form a cancer in our bodies can evade the immune system.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly explains immune evasion in pancreatic cancer, including desmoplastic stroma as a physical barrier, PD-L1 expression to engage PD-1 and turn off T cells, and low mutational burden reducing neoantigen visibility.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the immune system’s role in protecting the body from mutated cells that have oncogenic potential.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes immune system as identifying and destroying abnormal cells, with T cells as key effectors that seek and eliminate cancer cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a definition of immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines immunotherapy as treatment designed to reawaken and enhance the body's immune system to fight cancer, turning a 'cold' tumor into a 'hot' one.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the mechanism of action of immunotherapies in cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains mechanisms for checkpoint inhibitors (blocking PD-1/PD-L1), therapeutic vaccines (training immune recognition), and CAR T-cell therapy (engineering T cells to target tumor antigens).

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe features of pancreatic cancer that make this malignancy difficult to treat with immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes pancreatic cancer is immunologically 'cold' with dense stroma impeding T-cell infiltration and low mutational burden reducing neoantigens, leading to poor response to immunotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that there is research being done on the role of the immune system in pancreatic cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions active and rapidly evolving research, including clinical trials for vaccines, checkpoint inhibitors, CAR T cells, and combination strategies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient speak with his/her oncologist about clinical trials that might utilize immunotherapy for pancreatic cancer, or consider a referral to a center that does clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises discussing clinical trials with the oncology team and includes specific questions about immunotherapy trials and combinations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a limited number of pancreatic cancer cases have features that do make it respond to immunotherapy, such as MSI-H or mismatch repair deficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: States that a small subset (~1–2%) with MSI-H/dMMR can respond well to checkpoint inhibitors and that this is standard of care for those patients.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should ask the oncologist if her mother’s tumor has MSI-H or mismatch repair deficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: Directs the caregiver to ask if MSI-H/dMMR testing has been done and emphasizes testing as crucial.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cells that acquire mutations that can go on to form a cancer in our bodies can evade the immune system.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explains multiple immune evasion strategies in pancreatic cancer, including a dense fibrous stroma as a physical barrier, immunosuppressive cells (MDSCs, TAMs, Tregs), low neoantigen burden, PD-L1–mediated checkpoint exploitation, and immunosuppressive signaling within the tumor microenvironment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the immune system’s role in protecting the body from mutated cells that have oncogenic potential.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly outlines immune surveillance: recognition of abnormal cells by T and NK cells via neoantigens, activation to kill cancer cells, and development of immune memory to prevent recurrence.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a definition of immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Immunotherapy is explicitly defined as treatments that boost the body’s own immune system to fight cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the mechanism of action of immunotherapies in cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Mechanisms are accurately described for several modalities: checkpoint inhibitors releasing PD-1/CTLA-4 brakes, vaccines priming antigen-specific responses, adoptive cell therapies engineering T cells, and oncolytic viruses directly lysing tumor cells and activating immunity.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe features of pancreatic cancer that make this malignancy difficult to treat with immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It details key barriers: a cold tumor microenvironment, dense stroma limiting infiltration, immunosuppressive infiltrates (MDSCs, TAMs, Tregs), low neoantigen load, and lack of good targets—each making immunotherapy less effective.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that there is research being done on the role of the immune system in pancreatic cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: The response repeatedly references active and emerging research, ongoing clinical trials, and future combination strategies aimed at overcoming the tumor microenvironment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient speak with his/her oncologist about clinical trials that might utilize immunotherapy for pancreatic cancer, or consider a referral to a center that does clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly advises discussing options with the oncology team and asking if there are clinical trials that might be suitable.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a limited number of pancreatic cancer cases have features that do make it respond to immunotherapy, such as MSI-H or mismatch repair deficiency.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain what liquid biopsies are and how they are different from traditional biopsies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain the different uses of liquid biopsies in cancer care.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes multiple uses: monitoring treatment response, detecting recurrence, identifying resistance mutations for therapy selection, and assessing minimal residual disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention if liquid biopsy is FDA approved for any uses in pancreatic adenocarcinoma.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention FDA approval status for pancreatic adenocarcinoma in any context.
