criterion_scores.description: The response explains how cancer cells detect mechanical characteristics of their environment.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly explains detection mechanisms (integrins, cytoskeleton linkages, mechanosensitive ion channels), but this criterion carries no points per rubric.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains how cancer cells respond to mechanical characteristics of their environment.
criterion_scores.justification: It details responses to stiffness: increased proliferation/survival, invasion/migration using traction, gene-expression changes via nuclear deformation, and therapy resistance due to pressure and signaling.

criterion_scores.description: The response outlines how mechanosensing processes may be altered in pancreatic cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: It emphasizes a stiff, desmoplastic microenvironment and a vicious cycle with fibroblasts, but does not specify alterations in the cancer cells’ mechanosensing machinery (e.g., changed integrin profiles, FAK/YAP hyperactivation, Piezo/TRP changes) unique to pancreatic cancer cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines mechanosensing.
criterion_scores.justification: It provides a clear definition: the ability of cells to detect mechanical properties (stiffness, pressure, shape) and change behavior accordingly.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes mechanosensing in normal cells.
criterion_scores.justification: The general cell-based explanation (integrins, cytoskeleton, ion channels, nucleus) describes normal cellular mechanosensing independent of cancer context.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines desmoplastic stroma and describes its development in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It defines desmoplasia as dense, collagen-rich stroma, explains fibroblast activation by cancer cells, collagen deposition, tumor stiffening, and the reinforcing feedback loop.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes integrins, cytoskeleton, ion channels, and membrane sensors.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly describes integrins, the cytoskeleton, and mechanosensitive ion channels as membrane-based sensors, meeting all components listed.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains the YAP/TAZ pathway and its role in the development of desmoplastic stroma in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: YAP/TAZ is not mentioned or explained.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions if there are FDA-approved therapies that target the cancer cells’ ability to mechanosense.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses experimental strategies (stroma softening, integrin/FAK inhibition) but does not state whether any FDA-approved mechanosensing-targeted therapies exist.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how cancer cells migrate in response to cues from mechanical forces in their environment.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains stiffness-guided migration (traction on collagen fibers, following "stiffness highways"), capturing mechanotaxis/durotaxis-driven invasion.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines epithelial-mesenchymal transition.
criterion_scores.justification: EMT is not defined or discussed.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides published scientific journal articles as evidence for its statements and cites its sources.
criterion_scores.justification: No citations or references are provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains how cancer cells detect mechanical characteristics of their environment.
criterion_scores.justification: The response thoroughly explains detection via integrins, cadherins, ion channels, RTKs, and ECM stiffness; however, this criterion has a maximum of 0 points per the rubric.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains how cancer cells respond to mechanical characteristics of their environment.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly details mechanotransduction: focal adhesions (FAK/Src), cytoskeletal remodeling (actin–myosin, stress fibers), Rho GTPases, YAP/TAZ nuclear translocation, and downstream outcomes (proliferation, survival, EMT, ECM remodeling, drug resistance).

criterion_scores.description: The response outlines how mechanosensing processes may be altered in pancreatic cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes PDAC-specific changes: dense desmoplastic stroma, PSC activation, collagen/hyaluronan deposition and LOX cross-linking leading to stiffness; enhanced integrin/FAK/Src and YAP/TAZ activation; consequences including growth, invasion, chemotherapy resistance, immune evasion.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines mechanosensing.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a clear definition: cells detect physical forces (stiffness, tension, shear) and convert them into biochemical signals that affect gene expression and behavior.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes mechanosensing in normal cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses general cellular mechanosensing and contrasts normal soft conditions (YAP/TAZ phosphorylation and cytoplasmic sequestration) with stiff environments; explains baseline cytoskeletal probing and adhesion dynamics.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines desmoplastic stroma and describes its development in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines desmoplasia as stiff, fibrotic ECM and explains development in PDAC via activated pancreatic stellate cells producing excessive ECM (collagen, hyaluronan) and cross-linking (LOX).

criterion_scores.description: The response describes integrins, cytoskeleton, ion channels, and membrane sensors.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers integrins (and focal adhesions), cytoskeletal elements (actin–myosin, microtubules, intermediate filaments), mechanosensitive ion channels (Piezo1, TRP), and mechanosensitive behavior of RTKs; also mentions cadherins.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains the YAP/TAZ pathway and its role in the development of desmoplastic stroma in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains YAP/TAZ regulation by mechanical cues and nuclear translocation on stiffness; notes activation of genes including ECM remodeling, linking pathway activity to features contributing to desmoplastic stroma in PDAC.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions if there are FDA-approved therapies that target the cancer cells’ ability to mechanosense.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions investigational strategies (integrins/FAK, YAP/TAZ inhibitors, hyaluronidase) but does not state whether any are FDA-approved for targeting mechanosensing; no explicit FDA-approved therapies are identified.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how cancer cells migrate in response to cues from mechanical forces in their environment.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes durotaxis along stiff ECM ‘tracks,’ traction via actomyosin, shape change, and proteolysis (MMPs) to navigate dense matrix; links mechanical cues to enhanced motility and invasion.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines epithelial-mesenchymal transition.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines EMT as loss of epithelial traits and acquisition of migratory/mesenchymal characteristics, in the context of mechanosensing and metastasis.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides published scientific journal articles as evidence for its statements and cites its sources.
criterion_scores.justification: No references or citations to scientific literature are provided.

criterion_scores.description: Explains the normal flow of fluid from blood vessels to the extracellular space to the lymphatic system, including nutrient and oxygen delivery and waste management.
criterion_scores.justification: The response briefly implies normal physiology (blood delivers oxygen; lymphatics drain excess fluid), but it does not clearly explain the full normal pathway of fluid flow from blood to interstitium to lymphatics nor discuss nutrient/waste transport in a structured way. Therefore, it does not meet the full criterion.

criterion_scores.description: Describes how fluid flow becomes compromised in tumors, including increased intratumoral pressure due to abnormal blood vessels, poor lymphatic drainage, and dense stroma.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly describes leaky/abnormal blood vessels, collapsed lymphatics, and dense desmoplastic stroma leading to high solid stress and elevated interstitial fluid pressure, meeting all elements.

criterion_scores.description: Discusses the implications of altered fluid flow on cancer treatment, specifically mentioning reduced drug delivery and immune cell penetration.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states that compressed vessels prevent chemotherapy delivery and that high pressure/dense stroma impede immune cell (T-cell) penetration, fulfilling the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: Explains how increased interstitial fluid pressure impacts drug delivery, including uneven distribution of exposure in the tumor.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that high IFP reverses the pressure gradient, pushing drugs out and away from the tumor core, implying heterogeneous/uneven intratumoral distribution. Full credit warranted.

criterion_scores.description: Discusses the impact of altered fluid flow on radiation therapy due to hypoxia.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explains vessel compression causing hypoxia and that radiation is less effective without oxygen due to reduced free radical formation.

criterion_scores.description: Mentions the impact of altered cellular biology and extracellular structures on cancer behavior, including tumor growth, metastasis, and resistance to therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions hypoxia-induced survival signaling and resistance, it does not explicitly address tumor growth or metastasis in this context. The criterion requires inclusion of these elements.

criterion_scores.description: Describes how low flow to tumor tissue stimulates further cancer cell growth and development.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes hypoxia can make cells more aggressive and resistant, but it does not explicitly describe how low perfusion/flow directly stimulates further growth and development.

criterion_scores.description: Defines desmoplastic stroma and how pancreatic cancer encourages its development.
criterion_scores.justification: It defines desmoplasia as dense scar-like tissue produced by fibroblasts (stroma up to 90% of the mass) and explains that the tumor recruits fibroblasts to generate this matrix. Full credit.

criterion_scores.description: Defines interstitial fluid pressure.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly defines IFP as the pressure of fluid that builds up in the spaces between cells.

criterion_scores.description: Describes ways that increased pressure from interrupted fluid dynamics and desmoplastic stroma can cause compression on surrounding structures, leading to blockages and symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: The response focuses on intra-tumoral vessel compression and treatment delivery; it does not discuss compression of surrounding organs/ducts or related clinical symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: Provides specific published scientific journal articles as evidence of its claims, with proper citations.
criterion_scores.justification: No journal articles or citations are provided.

criterion_scores.description: Explains that poor fluid flow in tumor tissue is an active area of scientific research at this time.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states this is a major focus of modern research and lists ongoing strategies and a clinical trial example (PEGPH20), satisfying the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains the normal flow of fluid from blood vessels to the extracellular space to the lymphatic system, including nutrient and oxygen delivery and waste management.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes that normal tissues have low/slightly negative interstitial pressure facilitating movement of fluid and nutrients from blood vessels into tissue and notes that lymphatic vessels drain excess interstitial fluid. While brief, this covers blood-to-interstitium flow and lymphatic drainage (waste/clearance), and oxygen delivery is implicitly included under nutrient delivery.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how fluid flow becomes compromised in tumors, including increased intratumoral pressure due to abnormal blood vessels, poor lymphatic drainage, and dense stroma.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly attributes elevated IFP to disorganized/leaky vessels, poor lymphatic drainage, rapid proliferation, and particularly desmoplastic stroma in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses the implications of altered fluid flow on cancer treatment, specifically mentioning reduced drug delivery and immune cell penetration.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states reduced drug extravasation/penetration due to opposing pressure gradients and impaired convection/diffusion, and it explains the stromal/IFP barrier to immune cell trafficking and function.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains how increased interstitial fluid pressure impacts drug delivery, including uneven distribution of exposure in the tumor.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes that high IFP creates outward pressure opposing drug entry and that poor convection/diffusion leads to less drug reaching deeper tumor regions, leaving cells far from vessels 'shielded'—i.e., uneven intratumoral distribution.

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses the impact of altered fluid flow on radiation therapy due to hypoxia.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that elevated pressure impairs perfusion causing hypoxia, and hypoxic cells are more radioresistant because oxygen is needed to fix radiation-induced DNA damage.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the impact of altered cellular biology and extracellular structures on cancer behavior, including tumor growth, metastasis, and resistance to therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It connects microenvironmental changes (dense stroma, high IFP, hypoxia) to therapeutic resistance (radioresistance) and an immunosuppressive milieu, reflecting altered tumor behavior due to ECM/cellular changes.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how low flow to tumor tissue stimulates further cancer cell growth and development.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines desmoplastic stroma and how pancreatic cancer encourages its development.
criterion_scores.justification: While it defines desmoplastic stroma (dense fibrous ECM with collagen and hyaluronic acid) and emphasizes its prominence in pancreatic cancer, it does not explain how pancreatic cancer promotes its development (e.g., CAF activation, Hedgehog/TGF-β signaling).

criterion_scores.description: The response defines interstitial fluid pressure.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that normal tissues have low/slightly negative interstitial fluid pressure and that tumors have elevated/positive IFP, effectively defining IFP as the pressure within the interstitial space.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes ways that increased pressure from interrupted fluid dynamics and desmoplastic stroma can cause compression on surrounding structures, leading to blockages and symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions compression of intratumoral blood vessels and surgical challenges but does not address compression of surrounding organs/ducts (e.g., biliary or duodenal obstruction) leading to clinical symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides specific published scientific journal articles as evidence of its claims, with proper citations.
criterion_scores.justification: No journal articles or citations are provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains cancer metastasis in layman’s terms.

criterion_scores.description: The response gives examples of how cancer spreads in the body, including direct invasion by the tumor, spread through the lymphatic system, and spread through the blood.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers direct local invasion (ECM infiltration), entry into and exit from the bloodstream (intravasation/extravasation), and explicitly mentions the lymphatic system.

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses some of the cellular mechanisms by which cancer spreads in the body.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines extracellular matrix and cytoskeleton.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains cell adhesion processes.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that cells must detach from neighbors to escape the tumor and traverse endothelial gaps during intravasation/extravasation, reflecting adhesion dynamics, even without molecular detail.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how cell deformity changes in cancer cells as compared to normal cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Contrasts rigid normal cells (marbles) with deformable cancer cells (water balloons) and details cancer-associated softening via cytoskeletal changes and nuclear pliability.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes the impact of enhanced deformability of cancer cells on their ability to metastasize.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly states deformability is critical for metastasis and explains its role in tumor escape, ECM invasion, intravasation, survival in circulation, and extravasation.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how cancer cells with increased ability to deform survive stresses that normal cells would not.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that deformable cells better withstand shear and mechanical stresses in the bloodstream compared with more rigid cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes desmoplastic stroma in the pancreatic cancer tumor microenvironment.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically highlights the dense, stiff desmoplastic stroma in pancreatic cancer and its barrier-like nature.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains how increased deformability capabilities are necessary for cells to travel within the desmoplastic stroma of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States that pancreatic cancer cells must be exceptionally deformable to escape and traverse the dense stromal environment.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains cancer metastasis in layman’s terms.

criterion_scores.description: The response gives examples of how cancer spreads in the body, including direct invasion by the tumor, spread through the lymphatic system, and spread through the blood.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly describes local invasion (direct spread), entry into blood and lymphatic vessels (intravasation), travel in the bloodstream, and exit (extravasation).

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses some of the cellular mechanisms by which cancer spreads in the body.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions cytoskeletal remodeling, nucleus stiffness, changes in cell–cell adhesion molecules, interaction with endothelial barriers, ECM navigation, and responses to shear stress, all of which are cellular mechanisms involved in metastasis.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions epithelial to mesenchymal transition.
criterion_scores.justification: EMT is not mentioned or described.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions cancer metastasis as a response to cell stress.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains cancer cell deformability.

It mentions blood and lymph as 'rivers' but does not explain the typical movement of fluid from blood vessels into interstitial space and then into lymphatics under normal physiology.

criterion_scores.justification: Discusses ECM, collagen, fibroblasts, and their roles in tissue structure and signaling.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes desmoplastic stroma in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly notes pancreatic cancer’s dense, fibrotic desmoplastic stroma with excessive collagen.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes the effect of desmoplastic stroma on pancreatic cell proclivity to migrate and spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that stiff ECM transmits pro-invasive signals and that cancer cells remodel ECM to create channels facilitating migration.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the role of blood vessels in drug delivery, and how this can be impacted by pancreatic tumors and desmoplastic stroma.
criterion_scores.justification: States dense stroma and abnormal, leaky, disorganized vessels impede drug delivery and create hypoxic regions.

criterion_scores.description: The response clearly explains cancer metastasis in layman’s terms, avoiding jargon and providing accessible explanations.
criterion_scores.justification: Uses accessible language to describe tumor cells moving through tissue, entering blood/lymph, and traveling to distant sites, with minimal jargon and clear explanations.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly mentions all three main routes of cancer spread: direct invasion, lymphatic spread, and hematogenous spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions invasion into surrounding tissue (direct), entry into lymphatic vessels (lymphatic spread), and entry into blood vessels (hematogenous spread).

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses at least two cellular mechanisms by which cancer spreads, such as changes in cell shape, loss of adhesion, or influence of the microenvironment.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes changes in cell shape and polarity, and influence of microenvironmental stiffness/ECM remodeling on invasion and migration.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly mentions epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT) by name or describes the process.
criterion_scores.justification: While EMT is not named, the process is described via loss of epithelial polarity and adoption of mesenchymal-like, motile shapes enabling invasion.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions cancer metastasis as a response to cell stress, including stress-induced mechanisms.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not link metastasis specifically to stress-induced mechanisms; hypoxia and stiffness are discussed but not framed as stress-triggered metastasis.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends respectful and honest communication.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly promotes honest conversations with the mother about who to tell and what to share, sets expectations with trusted individuals, and suggests a unified message—all framed respectfully.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends maintaining personal boundaries.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises setting limits on visitors, letting calls go to voicemail, using canned responses to intrusive questions, and ignoring unsolicited medical advice—clear boundary-setting guidance.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends cancer support groups as helpful resources.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends support groups and specifically references the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN) for patient and caregiver support.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides examples of organizations with resources for cancer patients and their families and includes contact information or a website.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists CaringBridge.org (explicit website) and mentions PanCAN and Meal Train as resources, thereby providing at least one concrete organization with a website link.

criterion_scores.description: The response emphasizes the importance of a strong support system.
criterion_scores.justification: The entire "Circles of Trust" framework and suggestions to accept help and delegate tasks underscore building and relying on a strong support system.

criterion_scores.description: The response should inform the patient and family members that medical records are subject to HIPAA laws, which prevent divulgence of medical information unless a patient has specifically consented to this.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of HIPAA or legal protections regarding medical record confidentiality.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient inform their oncology care team of their wishes to keep their diagnosis confidential.
criterion_scores.justification: It does not advise informing the oncology team about confidentiality preferences.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient and family members be careful and thoughtful with social media posting to maintain her confidentiality.
criterion_scores.justification: It suggests using private Facebook groups and controlled one-to-many platforms, emphasizing sharing only what the patient is comfortable with—promoting careful social media use.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient and/or family members seek a balance; it is OK to be selective with sharing her diagnostic information however isolation for patients and/or caregivers can accelerate burnout.
criterion_scores.justification: While it promotes balance and selective sharing, it does not explicitly caution that isolation can worsen caregiver or patient burnout.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends respectful and honest communication.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly advises an open and honest conversation about the mother's comfort level and boundaries, emphasizes prioritizing her wishes, and suggests crafting a unified message with gratitude and clarity.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends maintaining personal boundaries.
criterion_scores.justification: It repeatedly highlights setting and enforcing boundaries (what to include/exclude, request for confidentiality, designating a spokesperson, controlled disclosure, and polite deflections).

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends cancer support groups as helpful resources.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends caregiver support groups offered by cancer centers and anonymous online forums/support groups as resources for emotional support.

criterion_scores.justification: Although it mentions Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN) and platforms like CaringBridge, it does not include any contact information or website URLs for these organizations.

criterion_scores.description: The response emphasizes the importance of a strong support system.
criterion_scores.justification: The 'Circles of Support' framework and repeated encouragement to lean on core supporters for emotional and practical help clearly emphasize the value of a strong support system.

criterion_scores.description: The response should inform the patient and family members that medical records are subject to HIPAA laws, which prevent divulgence of medical information unless a patient has specifically consented to this.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of HIPAA, protected health information, or legal privacy protections regarding medical records.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient inform their oncology care team of their wishes to keep their diagnosis confidential.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient and family members be careful and thoughtful with social media posting to maintain her confidentiality.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly advises avoiding broad social media unless the mother wants to share widely and notes difficulty controlling privacy on such platforms.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient and/or family members seek a balance; it is OK to be selective with sharing her diagnostic information however isolation for patients and/or caregivers can accelerate burnout.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it promotes balance and selective sharing, it does not explicitly warn that isolation can accelerate burnout for patients or caregivers.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains cancer metastasis in layman’s terms, avoiding jargon and providing context for a lay audience.
criterion_scores.justification: Uses clear analogies (escape artist), defines metastasis as spread to other parts of the body, and explains processes in accessible language while minimizing jargon.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly mentions and explains the three main routes of cancer spread: direct invasion by the tumor, spread through the lymphatic system, and spread through the blood.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions vessel and lymphatic walls in passing but does not explicitly name and explain all three routes (direct invasion, lymphatic, hematogenous).

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses at least three cellular mechanisms by which cancer spreads, such as changes in cell shape, breakdown of the extracellular matrix, increased deformability, use of filopodia/invadopodia, or epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT).
criterion_scores.justification: Describes actin–myosin-driven motility and protrusions, ECM degradation via MMPs, and increased nuclear deformability via lamin alterations—meeting the requirement for three mechanisms.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly mentions epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and explains its relevance to cancer cell migration and invasion.
criterion_scores.justification: EMT is not mentioned or explained.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions cancer metastasis as a response to cell stress.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not connect metastasis to cellular stress responses; only mentions DNA damage from nuclear squeezing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define the extracellular matrix.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines ECM as the dense meshwork around cells, providing a functional lay definition.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the different components of the extracellular matrix.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not list or describe specific components (e.g., collagen, laminin, fibronectin, proteoglycans, hyaluronan).

criterion_scores.description: The response should define desmoplastic stroma and describe how this is formed in the pancreatic cancer environment.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines desmoplastic stroma as dense, fibrous, scar-like tissue but does not describe how it forms (e.g., activation of pancreatic stellate cells/cancer-associated fibroblasts, signaling pathways).

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cancer cells are able to deform their shapes.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains cellular shape changes and nuclear deformation including lamin alterations that increase pliability.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain the cellular cytoskeleton and its main component parts, such as actin and myosin.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly explains cytoskeleton, actin-based protrusions, and myosin motor–driven contraction.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe amoeboid movement in cells and include a description of filopodia.
criterion_scores.justification: Amoeboid motility and filopodia are not discussed; only lamellipodia are mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe mesenchymal movement in cancer cells and provide examples of enzymes used by cancer cells in this phenomenon.
criterion_scores.justification: While MMPs are mentioned, mesenchymal movement is not explicitly described as a distinct migration mode.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide links to any scientific literature it references, including PMID.
criterion_scores.justification: No citations or PMIDs are provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain how cells can use ion gradients to prompt movement.
criterion_scores.justification: Ion gradients and their role in migration are not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the importance of pancreatic cancer cells’ ability to deform or “squeeze” in the desmoplastic stromal environment for survival and spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes that dense stroma is like a concrete wall and that highly deformable cells are needed to escape and metastasize in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include information about how the nucleus is thought to be deformable in cancer cell migration.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains nuclear stiffness as a barrier, lamin alterations that increase deformability, and consequences like rupture and DNA damage.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains cancer metastasis in layman’s terms, avoiding jargon and providing context for a lay audience.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly explains confined migration and metastasis in accessible language, defines terms as they appear, and provides context about where squeezing occurs.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly mentions and explains the three main routes of cancer spread: direct invasion by the tumor, spread through the lymphatic system, and spread through the blood.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists local invasion through ECM/around healthy cells (direct invasion), entry and exit from blood vessels (hematogenous spread), and movement through lymphatic vessel walls (lymphatic spread).

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses at least three cellular mechanisms by which cancer spreads, such as changes in cell shape, breakdown of the extracellular matrix, increased deformability, use of filopodia/invadopodia, or epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT).
criterion_scores.justification: Covers increased deformability/shape change, ECM degradation via proteases (MMPs), integrin-mediated adhesion, actin–myosin contractility, invadopodia, mechanosensing, and chemotaxis.

criterion_scores.description: The response explicitly mentions epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and explains its relevance to cancer cell migration and invasion.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly mention EMT or explain its role; mentions mesenchymal migration but not EMT.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions cancer metastasis as a response to cell stress.
criterion_scores.justification: No discussion of metastasis being triggered by cellular stress conditions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define the extracellular matrix.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines ECM as the scaffolding material outside cells and explains its nature.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the different components of the extracellular matrix.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists ECM components such as collagen, fibronectin, and laminin.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define desmoplastic stroma and describe how this is formed in the pancreatic cancer environment.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of desmoplastic stroma or its formation in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cancer cells are able to deform their shapes.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains cellular plasticity, cytoskeletal contraction, and nuclear deformability enabling cells to squeeze through tight spaces.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain the cellular cytoskeleton and its main component parts, such as actin and myosin.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes actin filaments, myosin motors generating contractile force, and mentions microtubules.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe amoeboid movement in cells and include a description of filopodia.
criterion_scores.justification: Amoeboid movement is described, but filopodia are not mentioned or described.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe mesenchymal movement in cancer cells and provide examples of enzymes used by cancer cells in this phenomenon.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes mesenchymal migration and cites matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) as proteases used to degrade ECM.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide links to any scientific literature it references, including PMID.
criterion_scores.justification: No citations or PMIDs are provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain how cells can use ion gradients to prompt movement.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of ion gradients or their role in cell motility.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the importance of pancreatic cancer cells’ ability to deform or “squeeze” in the desmoplastic stromal environment for survival and spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not discuss pancreatic desmoplastic stroma or its relevance to squeezing and survival.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include information about how the nucleus is thought to be deformable in cancer cell migration.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that the nucleus is large and stiff, but in cancer can be softer due to altered lamins/chromatin; also discusses nuclear positioning.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines topology.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly defines topology in context as the tissue 'city map'—the physical structure and connections (where cells are relative to each other and available pathways).

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how cancer spreads in the body, including direct invasion by the tumor, spread through the lymphatic system, and spread through the blood.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers all three routes: direct invasion via alignment and migration along collagen fibers; lymphatic spread to regional nodes; hematogenous spread via blood vessels with pancreas-to-liver drainage noted.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that in cancer care, topology may relate to the organization of tissues, blood vessels, or lymphatics.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly links topology to tissue layout and networks including ECM, blood vessels, lymphatics, and nerves.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the anatomic organization of cancer may impact the cancer’s stage or likelihood to respond to certain treatments like surgery or radiation.
criterion_scores.justification: States dense stromal topology impedes drug delivery (chemotherapy) and excludes immune cells, affecting treatment effectiveness. While surgery/radiation are not named, the criterion allows examples; treatment responsiveness is clearly tied to anatomic organization.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains cancer metastasis in layman’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Uses a clear city map analogy (highways, roads, tunnels) to explain how cells move via blood, lymph, and nerves in accessible language.

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses some of the cellular mechanisms by which cancer spreads in the body.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions perineural invasion, migration along collagen fibers, tumor–stromal signaling (fibroblast recruitment), and immune exclusion—mechanistic processes enabling spread.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe tissue networks and their component parts.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes cells, ECM, blood vessels, lymphatics, nerves, stroma, and immune cells as components of interconnected tissue networks.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define the extracellular matrix and describe its component parts.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines ECM as the physical infrastructure between cells and identifies collagen as a core component; further references collagen fibers within the stroma.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the desmoplastic stroma that pancreatic cancer encourages to grow in its environment.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly describes the dense, fibrous desmoplastic stroma characteristic of pancreatic cancer, with collagen-rich, scar-like tissue and activated stromal cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how abnormal tissue, such as desmoplastic stroma, increases in density of tissue network structures and encourages cancer growth and spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that dense stroma increases tissue density, blocks therapies, excludes immune cells, and provides aligned collagen tracks that guide invasion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the roles of blood and lymph vessels in cancer spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Details hematogenous spread through blood vessels (with pancreatic venous drainage to the liver) and lymphatic spread to nodes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain how disrupted tissue architecture can encourage cancer growth and spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes architectural remodeling—dense stroma, vessel collapse, aligned fibers, nerve tracts, and immune exclusion—as enabling tumor survival and dissemination.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe cell-to-cell adhesions in normal cells, and how cancer cells can disrupt these adhesions making them more able to migrate.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not address cell-to-cell adhesion mechanisms (e.g., E-cadherin) or how their loss facilitates detachment and migration.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how mechanical properties of tissue can stimulate tumor growth and spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes stiffness and alignment of collagen fibers directing invasion and elevated pressure collapsing vessels, both mechanical factors impacting spread and treatment delivery.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines topology.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines topology as spatial organization, connectivity, and structural integrity of tissues, focusing on how connections/arrangements are preserved or disrupted rather than precise shape.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how cancer spreads in the body, including direct invasion by the tumor, spread through the lymphatic system, and spread through the blood.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses direct invasion along ECM 'tracks', perineural invasion, and explicitly discusses abnormal blood and lymphatic vessels enabling tumor cell escape into the bloodstream and lymphatics leading to metastasis.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that in cancer care, topology may relate to the organization of tissues, blood vessels, or lymphatics.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly connects topology to tissue organization and describes vascular and lymphatic network organization as topological features.

criterion_scores.description: The response states the anatomic organization of cancer may impact the cancer’s stage or likelihood to respond to certain treatments like surgery or radiation.
criterion_scores.justification: While it notes effects on drug delivery and early dissemination, it does not explicitly relate anatomic organization to cancer stage or to response to surgery or radiation.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains cancer metastasis in layman’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Uses accessible analogies (dense forest, highways/tracks, escape routes) and plain language to explain how cells spread via tissue structures and vessels.

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses some of the cellular mechanisms by which cancer spreads in the body.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions loss of E-cadherin, altered integrin-mediated ECM interactions, mechanosensing of stiffness driving invasiveness, and perineural invasion—covering cellular mechanisms of dissemination.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe tissue networks and their component parts.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes tumor microenvironment networks including ECM fibers, stromal cells, glandular architecture, blood and lymphatic vessels, and nerves, and how they interconnect.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define the extracellular matrix and describe its component parts.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines ECM as the non-cellular structural scaffold and cites components such as collagen and hyaluronic acid; also discusses fiber alignment and stiffness. Note: minor inaccuracy listing fibroblasts as ECM, but definition and components are otherwise adequately covered.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the desmoplastic stroma that pancreatic cancer encourages to grow in its environment.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a detailed description of pancreatic cancer–associated desmoplasia, including dense ECM deposition (collagen, hyaluronic acid), fibrotic reaction, and its structural consequences.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how abnormal tissue, such as desmoplastic stroma, increases in density of tissue network structures and encourages cancer growth and spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains increased stiffness/density, raised interstitial pressure, drug penetration barriers, and aligned fibers creating migration pathways that foster growth and spread.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the roles of blood and lymph vessels in cancer spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis, describes abnormal leaky/tortuous vessels, hypoxia, and their function as escape routes into blood and lymph leading to metastasis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain how disrupted tissue architecture can encourage cancer growth and spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes loss of organized glandular structure and boundary breaches as key steps in progression; also links architectural distortion and ECM alignment to invasion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe cell-to-cell adhesions in normal cells, and how cancer cells can disrupt these adhesions making them more able to migrate.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states normal tight connections, describes loss of E-cadherin and altered integrin-mediated adhesion enabling detachment and migration.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how mechanical properties of tissue can stimulate tumor growth and spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Links increased stiffness and mechanical cues in the desmoplastic stroma to more aggressive behavior, invasiveness, therapy resistance, and elevated interstitial pressure.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.

criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends seeking support from a school counselor and a therapist specializing in childhood grief, which satisfies the counselor component.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends honest and open communication between patient and caregivers.
criterion_scores.justification: Honesty and openness are emphasized repeatedly (e.g., 'Honesty Builds Trust,' age-appropriate truthful explanations, addressing hard questions directly).

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends tailoring the discussion to the age of the children.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides detailed, age-specific guidance for ages 3–6, 7–12, and 13+, including example language and developmental considerations.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends cancer support groups as helpful resources.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions PanCAN and counseling, it does not specifically recommend cancer support groups.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides examples of organizations with resources for cancer patients and their families and includes contact information or a website.
criterion_scores.justification: PanCAN is named but no website, phone number, or other contact details are provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends establishing the patient’s goals of care.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no recommendation to discuss or establish goals of care, advance care planning, palliative care goals, or hospice considerations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of maintaining mental health throughout the cancer diagnosis and treatment process.

criterion_scores.justification: It normalizes the conflict by acknowledging the 'tightrope' between optimism and honesty and validates the difficulty of the situation.

criterion_scores.justification: It highlights focusing on comfort and meaningful days (quality of life) and mentions treatment effects like fatigue, hair loss, and feeling weak, which impact quality of life.

criterion_scores.description: The response should suggest that the patient and/or family members leverage support systems.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises leaning on friends and family for practical help and emphasizes using external supports like counselors and therapists.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with a social worker, spiritual worker, counselor, or Palliative Care specialist.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends seeking help from a child life specialist, family therapist, or grief counselor, which meets the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends honest and open communication between patient and caregivers.
criterion_scores.justification: It strongly emphasizes honesty and openness, including age-appropriate honesty, inviting questions, presenting a united message, and validating emotions.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends tailoring the discussion to the age of the children.
criterion_scores.justification: It provides distinct guidance for younger children, middle childhood, and adolescents with concrete examples.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends cancer support groups as helpful resources.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of cancer support groups is included.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides examples of organizations with resources for cancer patients and their families and includes contact information or a website.
criterion_scores.justification: No organizations or contact information/websites are provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends establishing the patient’s goals of care.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions focusing on comfort and quality time, it does not explicitly recommend establishing or discussing formal goals of care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of maintaining mental health throughout the cancer diagnosis and treatment process.
criterion_scores.justification: It encourages professional mental health support (therapist, grief counselor, child life specialist) and self-care for caregivers, emphasizing emotional wellbeing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that it is normal to feel this conflict in the face of a pancreatic cancer diagnosis.
criterion_scores.justification: It validates the difficulty and delicate balance of optimism and honesty and normalizes feelings like fear and sadness, meeting the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain quality of life, and describe factors of cancer treatment that can impact the patient’s quality of life.
criterion_scores.justification: It frames optimism around comfort and quality of life and mentions treatment-related changes (tiredness, pain, hair loss), which affect QoL.

criterion_scores.description: The response should suggest that the patient and/or family members leverage support systems.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises engaging teachers, school counselors, trusted family, and leaning on one’s support system.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes metastatic routes for pancreatic cancer, including local solid tissue invasion, hematologic spread, lymphatic spread, or perineural invasion.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses local invasion and mentions survival in the bloodstream with distant spread, but it does not clearly describe specific metastatic routes for pancreatic cancer (e.g., lymphatic or perineural spread), which are characteristic of PDAC.

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses cell-to-cell adhesions in both normal cells and cancer cells, highlighting differences.
criterion_scores.justification: Cell-to-cell adhesion via cadherins is discussed, but there is no explicit comparison between normal and cancer cells or how adhesion properties differ in cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions integrins and cadherins.
criterion_scores.justification: Cadherins are mentioned, but integrins are not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains cancer metastasis in layman’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Metastasis is clearly explained using accessible analogies, describing invasion, travel, and establishment at distant sites in lay language.

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses some of the cellular mechanisms by which cancer spreads in the body.
criterion_scores.justification: Mechanisms such as leader–follower dynamics, chemotaxis, ECM degradation by MMPs, and coordinated adhesion are described.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions epithelial to mesenchymal transition.
criterion_scores.justification: Epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains the biology of cell adhesion in layman’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Cell adhesion is explained using clear analogies (e.g., molecular Velcro, clasped hands) and functional descriptions of how adhesion allows group movement.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides published scientific journal articles as evidence for its statements and cites its sources.
criterion_scores.justification: No sources or journal citations are provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains the concept of “leader cells” and implies the presence of “follower cells” in a group of cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Leader and follower cells are explicitly described, including their roles.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes amoeboid movement in cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Amoeboid movement is not mentioned or described.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes mesenchymal migration in cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: While ECM degradation and protrusive movement are described, mesenchymal migration is not explicitly identified or contrasted; the criterion is not fully met.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines the extracellular matrix.
criterion_scores.justification: The ECM is defined as a complex network of proteins and sugars acting as scaffolding and a barrier.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines desmoplastic stroma.
criterion_scores.justification: Desmoplastic stroma is described as an intensely dense, fibrous, scar-like environment around PDAC.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how pancreatic cancer cells interact with desmoplastic stroma to encourage cancer cell growth and migration.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explains how cancer cells overcome the dense stroma via collective migration and MMPs, but does not describe how the stroma supports or encourages cancer cell growth or migration via reciprocal interactions.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains how “leader cells” influence a clump of traveling cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Leader cells are said to sense cues, secrete MMPs to clear paths, and pull the group forward while followers push, clearly explaining their influence.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines at least one other protein involved in cell-to-cell adhesions.
criterion_scores.justification: Only cadherins are discussed; no other adhesion proteins (e.g., claudins, occludins, desmogleins, selectins) are mentioned or defined.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how cells communicate with each other, such as through chemical signals or enzymes.
criterion_scores.justification: Chemical communication is described (cells release signaling molecules to coordinate), and enzyme-mediated ECM remodeling is discussed.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes metastatic routes for pancreatic cancer, including local solid tissue invasion, hematologic spread, lymphatic spread, or perineural invasion.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes local invasion (“breaking through physical barriers”) and hematologic spread via circulating tumor cell (CTC) clusters; frames this within pancreatic cancer’s aggressiveness. criterion_scores.description: The response clearly explains how changes in tissue density and architecture (cell jamming) influence cancer cell movement, tumor aggressiveness, and metastasis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response links crowding/jamming to reduced movement, describes unjamming enabling invasion/metastasis, and ties this to PDAC’s dense stroma and aggressiveness.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines and explains cancer cell jamming.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a clear definition using solid–liquid analogy, describes jammed state as high density with strong adhesion and force balance preventing motion.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines and describes cancer cells that are in an unjammed state.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains unjammed state as fluid-like with increased mobility, leader–follower dynamics, cell shape elongation, and weakened adhesions enabling movement.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how cancer cells become unjammed.
criterion_scores.justification: Details triggers for unjamming including emergence of leader cells, cytoskeletal force generation, cell shape changes, adhesion weakening, and ECM degradation.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes the intrinsic properties of cells that contribute to jamming and unjamming of cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions intrinsic features: adhesion molecule strength (molecular glue), internal motors/contractility, and cell shape changes contributing to transitions.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes the extrinsic properties of cells that contribute to jamming and unjamming of cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses extrinsic factors: tissue crowding, dense ECM/desmoplastic stroma in PDAC, and ECM remodeling via proteases creating escape paths.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains how unjamming of cancer cells contributes to cancer spread and migration of cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly connects unjamming to invasion and metastasis, describing collective flow, leader cells creating paths, and contribution to PDAC’s early spread.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains methods of cancer cell movement.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions independent vs group movement and leader–follower collective invasion but does not explain multiple movement modes (e.g., mesenchymal vs amoeboid) in detail.

criterion_scores.justification: It details cell-ECM adhesion via integrins, sensing of stiffness, and interactions with stromal cells within the TME.

criterion_scores.description: The response must define and describe the extracellular matrix, including its composition or function.
criterion_scores.justification: It defines the ECM as a network of proteins (collagen, fibronectin, laminin) and carbohydrates providing structural support and biochemical cues.

criterion_scores.description: The response must define and describe desmoplastic stroma in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes PDAC’s desmoplastic stroma as dense, fibrotic, collagen- and CAF-rich tissue that surrounds and infiltrates tumor cells and impedes therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explain the influence of the tumor microenvironment on tumor cell pattern formation, including at least one component.
criterion_scores.justification: It emphasizes the TME’s orchestration of patterns, naming components (CAFs, immune cells, endothelial cells, ECM) and their signaling cross-talk.

criterion_scores.description: The response must describe evolutionary pressures on cancer cells and the acquisition of DNA mutations, including at least one selective advantage.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes that genetic heterogeneity and natural selection favor traits like high motility and drug resistance, conferring selective advantages shaping tumor patterns.
